author: {'steamid': '76561198142452530', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 12942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1556108478}
review:
[h1]Guacamelee: AND HIS NAME IS DOM JUAN!![/h1]

Guacamelee, sortie le 21 aoÃ»t 2014, par la sociÃ©tÃ© indÃ©pendante DrinkBox Studios, est un jeu D'action-mÃ©troidevania vraiment ahurisant. MalgrÃ© la piÃ¨tre (pour moi) rÃ©ception qu'il a eu niveau vente, il devrait Ãªtre vraiment pour moi, beaucoup plus connu. Mais pourquoi? Je m'explique:

Histoire: 8/10

Dom Juan, agriculteur d'agave mexicain, doit aller sauver sa promise, la fille de El Presidente, des mains du cruel Carlos Calaca.
([strike]Boum Chacalaca[/strike]). Pour cela il devra franchir de nombreuses Ã©tapes et suplexer les sous-fiffres du vilain carlos (pas le calamar) afin de pouvoir atteindre son objectif. La diffÃ©rence entre les joueurs de Super Turbo Championship Edition et du Gold sont que l'histoire est lÃ©gÃ©rement modifiÃ©. Mais sinon, cela reste une trÃ¨s bonne histoire dans les deux Ã©ditions.

Graphismes: 9/10

Etant un jeu parlant d'une histoire ce passant au mexique, Guacamelee contient des graphismes colorÃ©s Ã  vous dÃ©foncer la vue. Sans dec', la qualitÃ© graphique pour un jeu indÃ©pendant 2D comme celui lÃ , c'est de la balle. Rien Ã  dire.

Gameplay/Game Design: 10/10

Du dÃ©but jusqu'Ã  la fin du jeu, vous apprendrez de nouvelles capacitÃ©s (plutÃ´t des prises de luchador) qui vous permettrons d'avancÃ© dans l'aventure. Il est aussi possible de trouvÃ© des fraguements de coeur, de crÃ¢ne, ou bien de talissement afin d'amÃ©liorer votre santÃ©, votre endurance, ou bien votre jauge de super luchador. GrÃ¢ce au systÃ¨me de monnaie, on peut aussi acheter des prises de lutte permettant de fendre encore plus de crÃ¢ne et Ã  faire encore plus mal. Certe, tout Ã§a est bien banal, mais pour moi, c'est parfait.

Bande Sonore: 9/10

Les sons et les musiques collent Ã  la perfection avec le thÃ¨me choisi et permettent au joueur de bien savourer les doux sons des guitares sÃ¨ches, et des bonnes raclÃ©es que vous mettez. 

Note Final: 94/100

Si vous voulez tout simplement mon avis, Guacamelee STCE est pour moi le jeu indÃ© de 2014, et est un chef-d'oeuvre que je ne me lasserai jamais d'y jouer. Le multi-joueur en vaut la peine aussi. MÃªme si il coÃ»te 14 euros, c'est un must have absolue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000368827', 'num_games_owned': 1253, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1553007800}
review:
This is almost a perfect game, amazingly well designed and balanced, buttery smooth, gorgeous visuals, amazing soundtrack, tons of good quality humor and references; a perfect iteration on the Metroidvania genre, improves what needed to be improved and dropped what needed to be dropped; you can play however you want, there are plenty of combinations of gameplay styles and a truckload of secrets and uprades to find and unlock. The game difficulty is pretty much perfect, easy and fun to play but hard to master, with plenty of optional challenges to try when you're feeling sassy; I've played ~9 hours so far and I'm not done with the main story yet, not to mention the optional stuff; I'm not sure what the replayability will be, but based on what I've seen, it's gonna be high. 

9.5/10, one of the best games I've played in years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006077632', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1520824037}
review:
Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition (STCE), where even the name is a reference. 

By Drinkbox Studios, who also made Severed (worth playing), Guacamelee is a Metroidvania/beat em up where you play as one Juan. I didn't catch a last name, but he probably has one. He dies, dons an Undead luchador mask, then chases after his childhood love who's been kidnapped. Which is a bit risky and unique for a plot, haven't seen it done before. Especially with a mute protagonist.

Having 100%'d both this and Gold, STCE is a flat improvement over Gold. Graphics improvements being the least of it, stuff like changing boss movesets so they go toe-to-toe with you instead of being puzzle bosses improves on some heavy issues I had with the original. That's without mentioning the changes to the forgettable challenges.

Regardless of the rest of the review, if you're choosing between this and Gold, go with this.

[h1]"Juan?? It's you?"[/h1]
[i]- There you, the damsel's entire arc in a nutshell[/i]

Juan rescues the damsel, I don't remember her name after two games, by following the large waypoint marker on his map to the next segment or boss. You can access side rooms off the main path for collectable upgrades, take a punch or two more to the face, but generally you're just lead by the nose which conveniently pokes out of the Luchador mask. 

Along the way, you fight a fair few enemy types with a combat system that is, in theory, alright. You hit an enemy with a launcher and can chain every special move together before landing. Combine with a basic combo and you can get some decent variation going on with your Luche Libre antics.

It's a shame that every single enemy in the game will either die midway into a combo, even on Hard, or will just break out of it whenever. It boils down to "launch enemies and alternate attacks to amuse yourself". 

Their idea of a challenging enemy type is one with undodgeable (just jump instead) attacks that breaks out of combos super early. Amazing.

[h1]"Poncho? Don't go into the light!"[/h1]
[i]- The combo chicken mourning his skeleton employee called Poncho. They think this is hilarious[/i]

You've got a jaunty soundtrack to all of this. I didn't have any problems with the music, but my roommate said it was drilling a hole into his skull so I don't know, take that one as you would. Aesthetics remain alright and they pushed the tween style to its limits, it worked out well.

So you've got an alright game, that isn't particularly mechanically special or notable but has a decent premise, right? So how'd they handle this, writing-wise?

With a constant litany of garbage, me-too referential nonsense and incoherent attempts at humour in every turn. Every screen is a reference, every dialogue is a reference or terrible pun. You never get away from it. And there's no kind way to say it isn't funny, but it just isn't funny.

[h1]"Oh no, you broke my Chozo statue!"[/h1]
[i]- Fuck you[/i]

Luche Libre beat-em-up with some exploration. That carries a game by itself, it didn't need any of this writing done so badly it's disgusting. No, 2008 memes, prattling on about mothers, puns or "dude ponchos and sombreros" is funny. None of it. It was awful to sit through.

Overall, Guacamelee is a fantastic premise, that has a pretty rote tired game attached that manages to drag, and is attached to some of the most obnoxious, grabbag, referential humour that'll make you taste bile. 

I recommend it to lobotomy patients and people who want to be disappointed in life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989091200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 1162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1162, 'last_played': 1519458443}
review:
Excellent platformer.

Gameplay:
Fluid, tight controls. A beat-em up that finds the perfect balance where it's not a mindless button masher, but also not so complicated that you need to memorize crazy combos (there is a part like in the training gym, but it's optional). You're able to pull off flashy combos if you care to, but even the simple stuff is fun and satisfying. The game has a lot of optional challenges as well if you want to push yourself to the limit. The game has plenty of secrets/upgrades (much like metroid, and the game isn't pretending that it isn't metroid-inspired). Parts of the game will require you to input some pretty complicated button combos to get through (relative to many other platformer type games), and the game is at its best when you're using all of your skills to get through stuff. The boss battles are also good, without ever devolving into a button masher.
There are also plenty of in-game unlocks, which is how things should be... so sick of "unlock the costume DLC".

Story:
Serviceable. The game sets up characters that you care about (both good and bad), with a "save the princess" goal (which is fine). Plenty of humour, plenty of references put in (although nothing is hamfisted in). The good and bad ending are both good and worth seeing.

Sound:
Soundtrack is very good, and the in game sounds are great as well.

Art/Environment:
Beautifully animated, with plenty of variety in the scenery... especially when you start going in between dead and living world, some of the variations are quite creative and beautiful to look at.


Overall:
This is a very good title. If I had to assign an arbitrary score, it receives a solid A- to A. (For reference: Hollow Knight recently took my top A+ spot, with Super Metroid coming in behind that somewhere).
If you like platformer/beat-em up/Metroid, and are interested in a more light-hearted, but still highly polished and fun game, pick this up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198295003615', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1478772390}
review:
This game's graphics are gorgeous not lying when I'm saying that I consider this one of the best metroidvania games I ever played a long with metroid, castlevania, Ori and the blind Forest and Outland for sure. The vibrant graphics are beautiful, the the power-ups were very creative and also how it makes nods to and poking fun at metroid element were entertaining as well the challenge room were very entertaining as I practise a lot to overcome it. Also the combat system was good with combos and the array of moves it's impressive. I find this game even better than Hollow Knight

As I would say every time I play this game "Let's Lucha"

author: {'steamid': '76561197994372877', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1518490941}
review:
As a game goes, it's okay. As a Metroid game, it's rather poor however. The level design stretches on and on but the areas never loop back on themselves.  As a consequence, the game really relies on you using the Moai Heads to fast travel too much.  But that's only between areas.  When traversing in a single area, there's rarely a way to quickly from one end of an area to another.  The game needed a few more shortcuts and/or the levels needed to intertwine a little bit more to be better. The combat is good, but the movement can be a bit sticky at times, causing some unnecessary headaches.

I recommend this game, but merely as an individual product. If you're looking for a good Metroid game, go somewhere else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065068952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1504036357}
review: Guacamelee is a classic in the metroidvania genre, and while much of the game feels somewhat dated by modern standards, it's still an excellent game. If you like metroidvanias to any degree, I highly recommend you get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998343607', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1517941684}
review:
â• Good soundtrack
â• Fun combination of Metroidvania and Beat 'em up.
â• Many improvements from previous release "Guacamelee! Gold Edition" such as: Multiple save files, Four player coop, New Boss and boss theme, Two new zones, Two new costumes, Two new powers, More enemies, Enemy Health bars, Change to power screens so they aren't as seizure inducing, improved design of breakable blocks and undodgeable attacks.

â– MEMES

Originally played Gold edition and got tired of it. Went back to play this version not really knowing all the changes and I had a lot more fun.
Totally recommend this to anyone who likes combo heavy violence where you throw skeletons around and juggle them in the air with punches.

Only negative I have to say about the game is the use of memes. They're everywhere and they aren't very funny. It's just memes in spanish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1516608515}
review:
I was not real pleased with the original Guacamelee, Iâ€™ll tell you that right now. What started off as a comical romp through a technicolor fantasy Mexico turned to acute frustration about halfway in. Too many aspects of the game left a bitter taste, like the complex fights and the punishing platforming and the secrets that werenâ€™t even clear on if they were obtainable or not. It was enough to ruin the game for me, and almost enough for me to ignore this edition of it. Thank goodness it didnâ€™t though, because the Super Turbo Championship Edition addresses my complaints so cleverly and so completely that it has rocketed up to one of my favorite platformers on Steam.

Juan is but a poor agave farmer on the outskirts of tiny Pueblucho, a town made notable by the sudden appearance of the skeletal Calaca. SeÃ±or Skelebones makes off with el Presidenteâ€™s daughter for a diabolical ritual, and Juan is felled trying to save his old flame. Luckily for him the worlds of the living and the dead are crossing at weird angles, granting him the divine power of the luchadores and another shot at life. On the trail of Calaca, Juan will discover a world of colorful landscapes and zany characters including Tostada the ghost luchadora, Uay Chivo the goat master, Flame Face the disgraced gunslinger, and even the devil himself. Oh, and there might also be a few hundred skeletons to beat up and items to find, too.

Guacamelee is a metroidvania in the modern mold of Outland and Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet, one with wide-open levels and very obvious gating. As you progress through the game youâ€™ll earn new moves like headbutts and uppercuts that  can destroy certain colors of blocks, allowing you to revisit previous areas and crack open their delicious secrets. Powers arenâ€™t just limited to combat moves either, because youâ€™ll score some obvious ones like double-jumping and wall-running and less obvious ones like turning into a chicken. Guacamelee also has the novel power to flip between two worlds (remember, the original Guacamelee dated from when this was still novel) and give you access to different platforms to scale and different enemies to suplex.

That last power is a pretty good example of what youâ€™ll face in your spirited romp. When you first gain it youâ€™ll use it to phase walls out of your way or make platforms up to new areas appear. Once youâ€™ve gotten comfortable with it youâ€™ll have to flip dimensions mid-jump to cross some hazards. And by the end of the game youâ€™ll be using it in conjunction with your mobility powers to run up one wall, phase through it, run up a second wall, phase through spikes, launch off the top and phase through six more pillars in your way. The movement and controls in Guacamelee are incredibly smooth and responsive, but they need to be to keep up with the borderline-absurd challenges youâ€™ll have to overcome with them.

Youâ€™ll be facing just as much resistance on the combat side of the game as well. Guacamelee is designed as a brawler, complete with combination attacks, grabs, launchers, air combos, and specials to mix into the, well, melee. Once you get the hang of it you can body slam a skeleton, boot him into his pals, falcon punch them into a flying uppercut and headbutt them into oblivion. You wonâ€™t need to do that, thankfully, but the controls make it easy enough to string attacks together into delicious smoothies of pain. What you will need to do is break colored shields with the corresponding powers, or wear down shields with repeated attacks, or shift dimensions to attack shadow enemies, or pound down exploding foes before they blow up the screen. Despite all of your neat moves the battles will still find ways to limit your options and kill you if you slip up at an inopportune time.

These two points, the complex combat and punishing platforming, were what put me off the original Guacamelee. Apparently the developers heard that from a lot of people, so they set about fixing it in this version. They smartly toned down a bunch of the platforming so that, while still difficult, itâ€™s not quite as maddening as it was before. The combat, though, they fixed in an absolutely brilliant way. Rather than change the encounters or challenges, they added a new system called INTENSO over the whole thing. When your INTENSO meter is full enough you can transform, making your attacks stronger, faster, and able to punch through shields no matter the color. Plus you can upgrade INTENSO to last longer and regenerate health, and you can turn it on and off at will as long as youâ€™re above the minimum. Itâ€™s an entirely optional system thatâ€™s a ton of fun to use, and lets you blow clean through any battle thatâ€™s giving you trouble.

I mentioned upgrades, and there are more than enough to keep even the most jaded metroidvaniahead busy here. Youâ€™ve got the common extensions to your health, stamina, and INTENSO meters, found in pieces in chests or from doing hilarious sidequests for residents. Then there are chests containing the gameâ€™s two currencies, coins for buying basic upgrades to your moves and silver for buying costumes with dramatic passive effects. If you are particularly daring you can also seek out the five gateways to Chac Mool, a secret realm that hides the key to the gameâ€™s good ending (which you will probably want, itâ€™s very sweet). This will require overcoming five very different challenges that will push your mastery of the game to its limits, though. Theyâ€™re clever in their designs and I enjoyed conquering them for the most part, but they are the kind of obstacles that can have you pulling hair.

Guacamelee isnâ€™t for the faint of heart, even with the upgrades of the Super Turbo Championship Edition. Itâ€™s not mean-spirited like Ori or foreboding like Hollow Knight but it expects you to master its mechanics to a level that most games donâ€™t. It does it with a smile, though, between the hilarious dialog and the zany characters and the cartoonish battles. The bright, bold, papered art style is absolutely perfect for the game, and the upbeat soundtrack will keep your blood pumping as you pound skeletons. I might not have appreciated it before but I adore it now, and I would put Guacamelee near the top of any platformer list just on fun factor alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198403964341', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1396, 'last_played': 1513321997}
review:
Soy MÃ©xicano y apruebo este juego :D
La ambientacion, es colorida y aun que que algo caricaturizada, representan de buena manera el folclor del lugar en el que se basa.
La jugabilidad es buena, apesar de que hay poderes opcionales que rompen con la dificultad del juego y lo hacen demasiado facil y de que aveces el tiempo de respuesta de los controles es demasiado rapida provocando un ataque doble.
Juego recomendado, aunque no he probado muchos juegos con este tipo de jugabilidad, tal vez piensen de otra manera los fanaticos este genero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124199218', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1514789315}
review:
Guacamelee is a colorful metroidvania styled platformer reminiscent of the older Super Metroid and Castlevania games. If you enjoyed playing these games chances are you will enjoy Guacamelee.

Pros:
+Beautiful Mexican themed world that feels unique.
+Responsive controls so no frustration.
+Great combo system which allows you to chain together combos easily.
+Easily earned currency in game which you can use to upgrade stats or change wardrobe to gain certain bonuses.
+Learning curve for the game isn't hard.
+Unique bosses to fight throughout the story.
+Pollo Power!, Yes you can turn into a fighting chicken.

Cons:
-Game can be a bit on the easy side since difficulty doesn't really come from the enemies but rather traversing obstacles and solving environmental puzzles.
-Game can be a little short especially for those only concerned with playing through the story. However if achievement hunting you could possibly get some more hours of gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198255276307', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1516065335}
review:
[h1] IntroduÃ§Ã£o	[/h1]

Guacamelee! STCE Ã© a versÃ£o definitiva de "Guacamelee", trazendo ajustes, novas fases e chefe e alguns elementos da jogabilidade. Trata-se de um Metroidvania com elementos de beat 'em up tendo o folclore mexicano como tema. Nele controlamos Juan, um aldeÃ£o que sonhava em ser um luchador, que Ã© morto pelo vilÃ£o Carlos Calaca, um esqueleto que deseja usar a filha de El Presidente num ritual que fundirÃ¡ os mundos dos vivos e dos mortos, para que ele governe sobre todos. No mundos dos mortos, Juan Ã© escolhido pela mÃ¡scara de um lendÃ¡rio luchador e retorna para enfrentar Carlos...


[h1] Jogabilidade	[/h1]

Guacamelee! STCE funciona como todo metroidvania. Um jogo 2D de plataforma com um vasto mundo aberto cujas "fases"desbloqueiam Ã  medida que o jogador adquire as habilidades necessÃ¡rias para alcanÃ§ar novas localidades, como pulo duplo, escalada e atÃ© voo. Seu grande diferencial se dÃ¡ pelo sistema de combate, um puro beat 'em up cheio de golpes e combos incrivelmente divertido com movimentos tÃ­picos de lucha libre. Um poder que permite transitar entre os dois mundos cria um fator chave no jogo e em seu sistema de transiÃ§Ã£o entre as fases e soluÃ§Ã£o de puzzles e missÃµes. HÃ¡ ainda o medidor "muy macho", uma espÃ©cie de modo berseker e uma das novidades desta versÃ£o do jogo.
Guacamelee! STCE pode ainda ser jogado por atÃ© 4 players, e possui uma variedade grande de skins que conferem habilidades aos personagens (Juan e Tostada), alÃ©m de suporte para as skins criadas na Oficina Steam.
Seus pontos fracos, sÃ£o dois. O primeiro, o jogo Ã© muito curto, podendo ser facilmente concluÃ­do em menos de 10 horas.
E o segundo, a forma como se apresentam os bloqueios de caminho do mapa. 90% deles se resumem a pedras coloridas que sÃ³ podem ser quebradas por uma habilidade de mesma cor. Isso tira um bocado do desafio, pois, ao invÃ©s de precisar descobrir como passar, qual habilidade nova irÃ¡ permitir que vocÃª prossiga, a informaÃ§Ã£o estÃ¡ lÃ¡ desde o comeÃ§o. 

[h1] Visual	[/h1]

A arte de Guacamelee! STCE Ã© simplesmente fantÃ¡stica. Sprites grandes, coloridos e muito bem animados, uma arte que combina o estilo cartunesco dos anos 2000 com a prÃ³pria arte mexicana e aqui um destaque para este elemento. Os cenÃ¡rios, os NPCs, inimigos e todo o mais sÃ£o cultura mexicana pura. A ambientaÃ§Ã£o Ã© perfeita, bela. Vilarejos, templos antigos, e atÃ© mesmo uma ilha de bonecas estÃ£o presentes. O jogo ainda faz inÃºmeras referÃªncias a jogos famosos nos diversos cartazes espalhados pelo seu mundo.

[h1] Som	[/h1]

O grande destaque sonoro vai completamente a trilha sonora, que assim como o visual, encorpora perfeitamente o folclore e a cultura mexicana. MÃºsica tradicional do MÃ©xico, e muito bem reproduzida, com uma versÃ£o normal e uma versÃ£o "Mundo de los Muertos" para cada faixa. Para quem aprecia folk, vale MUITO a pena comprar a trilha sonora do jogo.

[h1] Em suma...	[/h1]

Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition Ã© um jogo demasiado divertido. Um metroidvania muito bem construÃ­do com um sistema de combate divertido e empolgante. Desafiador na medidade certa, com personagens carismÃ¡ticos e um conteÃºdo robusto de cultura e folclore mexicano. A falta de criatividade nos bloqueios de caminho do jogo pode ser algo negativo, mas, nÃ£o ofusca o brilho desta obra, ela apenas poderia ser ainda melhor. Seu Ãºnico problema mesmo Ã© ser curto, mas, o elemento multiplayer e o desejo de completar o 100% do jogo podem manter aceso o desejo de um replay.


[h1] NOTA	[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198126975019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 753, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1659365481}
review:
It's a very beautiful game.

It has an incredible concept based in the idealization of Mexican culture, the whole game plays like a fantastical tale from old times, the characters, and universe, are fantastic, the story is interesting, and filled with charm.

The aesthetic, and, or, art style, is beautiful, and distinctive, incredibly colorful, and goes perfectly well with the themes that this games deals with.

The game design its fantastic, incredibly simple, and straightfoward, yet intelligent, and with a lot of depth.

The puzzles, platforming, and combat systems, and areas, are fantastic, different, and enjoyable to play through.

The game also has great replayability with upgrades, secrets, and different endings to achieve.

It might also be one of the few "metroidvanias" that I like because it actually gives you a general idea to which area you need to go next.

It is a very intuitive, casual, yet deep, intelligent, and beautiful game.

Totally recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078437944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1375, 'last_played': 1566687429}
review:
So I am adding one to the many positive reviews, becasue its a absolutely fantastic game!!
I'm not even that far into it yet hour-wise but it has

+ very original nice and capturing story (this one of the few games that just kept me playing and playing  because I was simply sucked into it and its story and wanted to know how things will continue. That is what a game should be like!!)
+ awesome artstyle
+ very nice music
+ funny elements (in conversation of the characters or also gameplay/story-wise)
+ cool fighting combos that you actually have to use in many parts of the map to get on with the game (and I'm saying that as someone who doesnt even have a controler)

I do understand some people are upset that this game is like a re-relaease of previous versions except that it has a bit more content. I was lucky enought to buy the game now when the other versions have been out for a long time, so I could just see which one is the best version. But I guess not everything always goes smoothly in life so maybe the game coming out like this (again) was just how things went. 
Nevertheless the game for itself is awesome and I cant even remember but i think it has differen difficulty settings and at the moment I'm on normal. So after I finish I really wanna try the others too which means theres a lot of content.

Haven't found any cons yet really.
Definitely recommend!

EDIT: Game is so absolutely awesome!!!!! ^_^ I used to have a note here that said my rating goes down a bit because of the games ending, but now I came back to change that becasue what I was thinking before doesnt apply (as much) anymore. (Don't want to mention what it was as not to spoiler, but as I said my former point is irrelevant now anyways ;) )
Therefore no minus for this awesome, challenging, graphically and acustically beautiful game!!!
Buy buy buy now! You will not regret it!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045637460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1652688694}
review: Great Game ! A solid Metroidvania style game with fantastic art and music that really brings theworld to life. The combat is great and the levels keep you going forward with little back tracking needed though recommended for final boss where the game revs up the difficulty. The side quests are few but memorable and theres tons of easter eggs from games such as Journey, Mario and Castle Crashers. It can be beat in under 10 hours but if you explore every nook and cranny for power ups it can take around 15 hours in total. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198019112527', 'num_games_owned': 1395, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1511841508}
review:
Very fun game, i liked the art, the story, the characters and the power ups and the music. It's defined as metroid style because with the new abilities you earn you need to go back t different areas to do stuff.
The first problem about the game were the shield auras, i couldn't differenciate between the different colors and was problematic, because i needed to use 3 different ways to break a single shield because i didn't know what attack to use.
The secon problem is that some boss battle, especially the last one to make it more difficult just increases the damage and the lenght of the attacks so they ocuppy more screen space. I read that was a cheap trick to make a game "difficult", the problem also cuphead suffers. 
The ending is pretty cute.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070032058', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1511741583}
review:
Hello there. I bought this great looking game due to the positive reviews and the fact that I like 2D action games such as Dead Cells and Ori. Usually I am not afraid of ingame challenges, but this game has started to really upset me due to the combination of bad controls, very challenging jumping sequences and unfair mob AI. I will try to sum up my personal pros and cons below.

Pros:
+ great music (at start)
+ funny main character
+ possible co-op
+ nice graphics and design
+ stable game (so far)
+ fair price and content

Cons:
- very annoying music (might be due to the countless retries...)
- several try & error jumping sequences
- unfair enemy mobs (e.g. shielded enemies hid in corners stacked up on each other)
- inaccurate and overloaded controls (makes fights and agility sequences very hard)

At the time of writing I had to give up mid-game and I am not sure, if I will give this game another chance...

This is really wrong and unethical from the devs. I also nominated this game for the 2017 write-in award "Most Devious Devs". I had already played and finished the first game. It really is an excellent game, but can't recommend out of principle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041710437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2553, 'last_played': 1492292602}
review:
If you're wondering if this game is worth buying or not, just buy it already!

I first played Guacamelee Gold Edition in Normal Mode, and thought it was awesome.
Then I played it again in Hard mode for the achievements, and enjoyed it very much.

When Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship edition came out, I had my doubts if it was worth, for someone who had already beaten Guacamelee Gold Edition twice, with 100% conclusion... but now, I tell you: IT IS!!!

This version of Guacamelee improved what was hard to improve. Added more characters, scenes, enemies, skill, maps, all while exploring Tostada's past and telling her story (!).

This new version gave me several new hours of gameplay, and got me and my girlfriend so hooked that we played Normal Mode and Hard mode on my steam, and are planning on doing it in hers, too (we also already bought it for her account!).

That's how good this game is. I'm seriously expecting a sequel in the future. Games of this level surely deserve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198178462658', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1511272175}
review: I love this game but, it has it problems.  Mostly with the controls, for me I played with a controller and as I was playing the dodge kept going off mid-air for some reason for me which made it hard to do jumping sections but I ignored it.  About the wall jump mechanics,  it was a great concept but grabbing to walls was a pain and I barely grabbed to walls without it failing horridly because of the game no being able to tell I was on a wall or dodging (might have been my controller being unresponsive).  Other than that it's a good game and basically the same as GOLD edition but with some improvements.  The enemies has great designs but felt weak and the throwing the enemies made the game feel too easy which makes me wonder why hard mode was locked until you beat the game.  Also the bosses were great with great designs and fights which weren't too hard but were tough enough so you feel joy when beating them.  I beat this game and got the true end and I'm happy to wait for the upcoming sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206999976', 'num_games_owned': 1110, 'num_reviews': 510, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1510937646}
review:
[h1]Review zu Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition[/h1]

GUACAAAMELEEEEE! SUUUUPPPEEERR TURBO CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION!
Und so schreit dich das Spiel beim Starten an. Es zeigt schon von Anfang an, welche Art von Spiel man sich da gekauft hat. Eines das sich selbst nicht ernst nimmt und es dem Spieler unter die Nase reibt.
Ich muss ernsthaft gestehen, dass ich ursprÃ¼nglich hÃ¶here Erwartungen an Guacamelee hatte. Ich habe einst von diesem Spiel gehÃ¶rt, nachdem es als "eines der besten unbekannten Metroidvania" betitelt wurde. Tja, da hab ich wohl meine Erwartungen zu hoch geschraubt. Versteht mich nicht falsch, das Spiel ist gut, hat jedoch so seine Macken.
Besonders lobend mÃ¶chte ich noch den Humor des Spiels erwÃ¤hnen. Dieser wird nicht jedermanns Sache sein, aber mindestens ein kleines Schmunzeln wird wohl fÃ¼r jeden drin sein!

Kommen wir fÃ¼r die Schnellen unter uns einfach mal zur Pro-Contra-Liste:

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]

+ Stimmiger Soundtrack mit lateinamerikanischem Flair
+ Koop vorhanden
+ Der Humor des Spiels ist stellenweise echt lustig und manche Charaktere sind einfach nur zum SchieÃŸen. Verraten mÃ¶chte ich da jetzt nichts.
+ sehr kurze Ladezeiten
+ Diverse Anspielungen auf andere Videospiele, Filme und Serien. Da wÃ¤ren z.B Super Mario, Metroid, How I met your Mother, Star Wars etc. (Ich habe bestimmt noch nicht alle entdeckt!
+ Das Kampsystem ist erschlagend! Es fÃ¼hlt sich einfach nur groÃŸartig an Skelette zu verdreschen!

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]

- deutsche Ãœbersetzung ist fehlerhaft
- Falls die V-Sync aus ist, so gibt es ein kleines Flackern auf der horizontalen Achse des spielbaren Juans. Irgendwie nervig und mit nur 60 FPS mÃ¶chte ich nicht spielen...
- Selbst wenn ich mit dem GamePad spiele werden mir manche Tasten bei der Bedienung der Karte noch in der Tastaturvariante angezeigt.
- Es gibt eine Gegnerart, die Knochen auf dich wirft. Sollte man gegen eine Ã¼berschaubare Anzahl von Gegnern kÃ¤mpfen so kann man diese gut sehen und auch entsprechend ausweichen, doch in manchen Stellen des Spiels ist dies einfach zu penetrant... Ãœberall riesige Gegner, kleine, schnelle und diese roten Skelette die einen mit Knochen abwerfen... Irgendwann ist es ja dann wohl mal genug oder?

[u][b]Prontra:[/b][/u]

+- Durch den Skelettshop renne ich am Anfang des Spiels gefÃ¼hlt jede Minute hindurch. Liegt allerdings daran, dass dies die Speichermethode des Spiels ist. Dennoch irgendwie nervig, da dann das Spiel fÃ¼r Bruchteile einer Sekunde stoppt. Jedoch sind die Checkpoints sehr fair platziert, selbst im letzten Teil des Spiels.
+- Die Symbole auf der Karte sind mir zu groÃŸ.
+- Die Bosslebensanzeige ist in der vorherigen Cutscene, oder Diskussion wenn man so will, oben einsehbar und nimmt einfach die Spannung, ob man einem Boss gleich gegenÃ¼berstehen muss oder nicht. Sehr schade eigentlich...
+- Sollte man von einem Gegner getroffen werden, so ist die [i]Knockoutzeit[/i] (nennen wir sie jetzt einfach mal so) deutlich zu lang. Man wird sogar richtig zurÃ¼ckgestoÃŸen. HeiÃŸt man wird dermaÃŸen bestraft, wenn man in einem Raum voller Gegner mal getroffen wird, was fÃ¼r normale Menschen ansich eigentlich kaum unversehrt mÃ¶glich ist.
+- Die FÃ¤higkeiten, die man sich im Laufe des Spiels erwirbt, um neue Gebiete zu erkunden, sind irgendwie einfallslos, aber was will man anderes erwarten, wenn man mit seinen FÃ¤usten, FÃ¼ÃŸen und seinem Kopf kÃ¤mpft... Die FÃ¤higkeiten sind halt eigentlich nur diejenigen, dass man verschiedenfarbige BlÃ¶cke zerstÃ¶ren kann. Naja.
+- Steuerung kÃ¶nnte manchen etwas zu fummlig sein, aber wie sagt man so schÃ¶n? Ãœbung macht den Meister!

Ich kann das Spiel also empfehlen. Habe mir persÃ¶nlich mehr FÃ¤higkeiten gewÃ¼nscht um mehr Abwechslung zu garantieren, aber dennoch ist Guacamelee ein Spiel, dass definitiv von jemandem mal gespielt werden sollte, dem das Metroidvaniagenre liegt! Der Normalpreis von 13,99â‚¬ ist ansich in Ordnung und ein sehr fairer Preis!

Ich danke fÃ¼rs Lesen und wÃ¼nsche sehr viel SpaÃŸ beim Spielen! ;-)

http://store.steampowered.com/app/275390/Guacamelee_Super_Turbo_Championship_Edition/

author: {'steamid': '76561198116361480', 'num_games_owned': 41, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1289, 'last_played': 1510671930}
review:
Che dire..un buon Metroidvania/platform,divertente e spensierato. Dal mio punto di vista un gioco abbastanza facile anche alla modalitÃ  difficile(non che sia un difetto,ma io personalmente preferisco un po di sfida in piÃ¹),platinato in circa 20ore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026637457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1510623795}
review:
Started this expecting a Metroidvania as a brawler, and it is. The metroidvania elements are pretty bad though, felt pretty linear and was always guided where to go.
However, this is some fantastic combat. Feels somewhat similar to a Smash Bros game, and you know we don't get that Subspace Emissary anymore. Very simple combat commands, all are just a single direction+a button, and they all have great crowd controls, throws, and can chain them easily. Only problem I would have is dodging enemies is too easy, felt like I was a psycho just mindlessly attacking everyone. Enemies lose their attack animation when you attacked them, so once you get that first punch in, it becomes easy. There's lots of gigantic guys where this is not the case, but it's still too easy to dodge them. Maybe this problem is solved on hard, but overall the enemies themselves are lacking in AI and attacks.
The setting is great, but the music is very lacking. It's not bad, but it feels like there were only 5 songs the entire game.
This game is great, but I hope the sequel expands on all it's shortcomings. The potential is all there.

review:
De lo mejorcito en juegos indie. Estilo metroidvania con graficos coloridos y una estetica y ambientaciÃ³n sublime
El juego tiene una historia sencilla pero muy divertida. Te encontraras referencias a Metroid FusiÃ³n, Grim fandango, Super mario entre otros. 

AmbientaciÃ³n Mexicana mezclada con ese toque del dÃ­a de los muertos muy coherente y acertada

+Animaciones pulidas
+Controles bastante pulidos
+Multijugador local hasta 4 jugadores
+2 Finales en funciÃ³n de los coleccionables
+BSO muy buena
+Personajes (sobre todo los enemigos) Muy carismaticos y chocantes
+DuraciÃ³n 8-10h a ritmo pausado pero invita a rejugarlo para conseguir ambos finales

9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198336608168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 2028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1280, 'last_played': 1538738608}
review:
Manqueando, episodio taytantos. Hoy... Guacamelee.

Debo reconocer que cuando me lo comprÃ©, fue mÃ¡s por oir decir esto o lo otro que por convicciÃ³n. La verdad es que no me llamaba la atenciÃ³n ni lo mÃ¡s mÃ­nimo. Y despues de ver 10 min. en casa de un amigo, me diÃ³ por jugar. Tenian razÃ³n.

El asunto es un metroid de manual, que incluso se toma licencias de la saga de nintendo. Plataformas, combate, mejoras, backtracking... todo lo que necesita un juego de este tipo, pero ademÃ¡s con mucho sentido del humor, y con un buen nivel de calidad en todos sus apartados. La dificultad es en algunos momentos desesperante, pero no siempre.

Lo Ãºnico malo que le he visto es que en ocasiones, durante los combates la cosa se vuelve un poco confusa, llegando a perder de vista el nino por segundos. No es que sea muy frecuente, pero ocurre.

Las cosas buenas no las voy a poner, mejor las descubrÃ­s vosotros jugando, como debe ser.

Asi que le cascamos un 8'5 y cooooÃ±o, claro que lo recomiendo!

En el proximo episodio de Manqueando... "Momodora Reverie under the musgo"

author: {'steamid': '76561198241040582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2153, 'last_played': 1510552760}
review: Guacamelee STCE has the perfect balance of ridicule, story, arena fighting and challenging levels. It's an amazing platformer that will make you chuckle more than once and make you burst a vein from all that screaming at your screen. The main storyline is not that hard to beat, but if you're a completionist like me, you're in for a wild ride. The (extra) levels are absolute hell, but incredibly rewarding and once you're done, you'll wish you had more. I don't intend on playing the other versions of Guacamelee, this edition had it all for me. Also, I must say that as a Mexican it was an incredibly gratifying experience to see a game with our culture being pretty much its only influence, treated with such humorous tones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009956005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1509522341}
review:
Game World, Story and Theme
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania.  The level design is solid and the locations varied.  There is quite a bit of optional content to play through and explore.
The game has a Mexican theme.  This is exceptionally well done and infuses every aspect of the game.  The visuals are beautiful and detailed.  The soundtrack is one of the best I have encountered.
The story is simple, but beautifully told.  The game has a great sense of humour, and the characters you meet are highly memorable.

Gameplay
Guacamelee is a beat-em-up with a focus on combos.  It is intense and fun and has a dynamic and forgiving combo system.  The combat has a feeling of weight and impact.
There is also a strong platforming element.  This is very well done, as it presents creative challenges to overcome.  Platforming often involves an element of puzzle solving.
Exploring the levels is fun, as you gain some neat abilities as you progress.  The combat and platforming can both be quite difficult at times, and some of the optional content can be extremely difficult indeed.

Conclusion
Guacamelee is a delightful and funny game with a memorable theme and awesome, varied gameplay.  I would highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1643039701}
review:
Tags: Platformer - Metroidvania

TLDR: Its an instant classic basically.

With heavy brawler influences. Guacamelee has excellent Xbox360 pad support. Additional players can hotswap join at any time during single player campaign on local co op by push of a button. Decent complement of graphical options and real PC monitor resolutions support. Controls are fluid and slick, mapping on controller is intuitive and makes sense. Level design is a bit confusing to me but I am not a veteran of metroidvanias. Game has awesome animations, decent sprites and character models, and great audio presentation. Menus are slick UI is mostly unobtrusive and helpful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085484172', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1508697497}
review:
Came in for the metroidvania, stayed for the surprisingly deep combo system. It's pretty much Mahvel. [spoiler]There is even an XFactor, not kidding[/spoiler]

Throw in some great humor and great level design and you have a perfect combination that is fun throughout it's entirety, [i]and I'm including the scavenging for the last collectibles for that 100%[/i].
Simply put, it controls great, it feels great, it sounds great and overall, it plays great.
Extremely fun in coop as well, I highly recommend going through it with a friend or two if you have the chance, although it is fun in solo as well.
Highlights to those hellish "secret" optional hardcore platforming sections.

It also has what the majority of non-AAA (and even some AAA lately...) games lack.
Proper localization to various languages. Even puns are localized, and very well.
I can't say anything about the other languages, but the spanish translation is [i]flawless[/i].

The only gripe I would have with the game is the final boss being a bit too easy relative to the other bosses.
It hasn't given me near as much grief as the damn four-armed wrestlers.

All in all a real 10/10 you should absolutely play

author: {'steamid': '76561198059321573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1508601957}
review:
I'm a big fan of metroidvanias, and this was on my bucket list of metroidvanias to play. I have to say, I was pretty disappointed:

The difficulty is too easy until the last parts of the game. I'm not asking for the game to be Dark Souls, but I expect the difficulty to be somewhat consistent, and if the game is going to be making Metroid references, I expect it to not be a complete pushover. Instead, the early and middle parts of the game give you so much health, health regen, and health-refilling checkpoints that I could carelessly walk into attacks without consequence and beat most bosses first try. At least the last sections of the game put up a fight.

The "gates" that stop your progress until you find the appropriate item feel so bland. In other metroidvania games, you might have a platform that can't be reached until you get double jump/dash, or a piece of the environment you can't interact with until you get a specific item. I mean, a veteran of metroidvanias could easily recognize the gates when they see them, but at least those try to be a bit subtle or creative. In Guacamelee, you break yellow blocks with the yellow power, red blocks with the red power, blue blocks with the blue power, etc. It reminds me of Fischer Price toys where you put the square in the square hole and the circle in the circle hole.

The level design is bland. I can remember about two areas of the game. The color palettes, textures, themes, enemies, and room layouts of the areas are homogenized to the point where I can barely tell them apart. The jungle area feels like "rocks with grass", the desert area feels like "rocks with sand", the temple area feels like "rocks with engravings". Every single area of the game has the same kinds of enemies. The platforming manages to be more distinct from area to area, so I'll give the game credit for that. Compare this to a game like Hollow Knight, where I can remember almost every single area of the game because they all have distinct textures, color palettes, themes, enemies, etc. Hell, the entirety of Castlevania Symphony of the Night took place inside a castle and I can remember its areas better. Maybe the individual regions of Guacamelee are too small to properly develop any real personality.

On top of the areas being so forgettable, they feel very unrewarding to explore. The level design is incredibly linear, so most of the time, you're just going straight along the path the game tells you to go along. The linear level design also makes the secrets incredibly easy to spot: if you see a branching path, that's a treasure chest, go grab it. Remember those colored blocks I mentioned earlier? The map labels every single one of those automatically, so you basically already know where to go if you're backtracking to discover secrets you couldn't get on your first run through an area. Oh, and basically every single treasure chest in the game is either money, health, or stamina. The only interesting rewards you'll find are the mask pieces.

The enemies have no variety. The majority of the enemies are skeletons. You got regular skeletons, skeletons that throw bones, fast skeletons, big skeletons. The endgame skeletons are basically the same as the early game skeletons, except they have shields, or are elite, or come in massive numbers, something along those veins. The bosses would are actually kind of interesting, but unfortunately, most of them are complete pushovers.

I'll give the game credit for its good art, good music, and somewhat enjoyable combat and platforming.

Overall, the game wasn't bad, it was just mediocre. Why settle for mediocre when there are great games though? Before you consider this game, go buy Hollow Knight, Ori and the Blind Forest, Momodora, Axiom Verge, or any of the countless metroidvanias on Steam that are so much better than this first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996305573', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1506528746}
review:
I'm a bit torn on giving Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition (STCE) a thumbs down, but I feel it's important for prospective buyers/players to know that STCE is significantly worse than Guacamelee! Gold Edition. 

STCE brings a number of modifications to Guacamelee, all of which are negative (apart from the 4P support). First, there are two large new areas, both of which serve as filler, breaking the flow of the game while not introducing any new concepts. Arguably the best part of the second area is the new character that serves as a boss, but said boss fight is relatively simple and the character takes focus away from the stronger original cast. Secondly are the combat changes: the "rebalancing" of enemies and the Intenso power. Javiar Jaguar, the stand-out boss from the original game, has been nerfed to an absolute pushover. Moreover, the Intenso power is absolutely game breaking, making every combat encounter in the game a joke. That wouldn't be so bad if you could ignore it, but the developers added certain combat encounters where the difficulty goes through the roof if Intenso isn't used (rooms with multiple enemies with white shields, hitstun-immunity, and/or non-dodgable attacks).  These rooms generally feature Intenso-refilling barrels or enemies as well, so the intention is clear. Of course, there's plenty of Intenso to go around even for easier rooms and bosses, trivializing combat entirely. 

In short, STCE is still a good game, but the original release was a GREAT game, without the broken combat "rebalancing" and padding. Please buy/play Guacamelee! Gold instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976370569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1468248249}
review:
Rarely do games get love from all aspects, gameplay, sound and visual design. This is one of the more enjoyable experiences I have had in a game - though a bit simplistic, the tight controls, sound level design and visual diversity do not limit the enjoyment throughout. The soundtrack is amazing, dabbling through latin interludes and matching soundtrack change with visual change. The pre-fight and running section tracks are worth the price of admission alone. In a stark defiance of the greys/browns etc of recent releases, Guacamelee is beautifully bright and vivid - visually stimulating, unique and the overall design is a positive that you will keep with you after finishing the game.

In short, a fun, bright and audibly well presented game. Though not a super challenging experience, enjoyable throughout and a worthwhile gaming experience.

review:
Guacamelee STCE Ã©, sem sombra de dÃºvidas, a versÃ£o definitiva.
Para aqueles que jÃ¡ jogaram a versÃ£o original, caso esteja em promoÃ§Ã£o, vale a pena comprar.
A trilha sonora Ã© muito boa, combina com o os cenÃ¡rios.
O jogo possui muitas referÃªncias Ã  outros jogos; os diÃ¡logos sÃ£o cheios de humor, o jogo Ã© muito divertido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188469585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1335, 'last_played': 1584150438}
review:
Pros
Beautiful graphics, good soundtrack, and variety. The way the game uses abilities you learn in different ways over time for platforming segments really amazes me. The way a side dash could be used to break a specific block but then you must immediately switch dimensions to avoid a hazard and then take out the enemies is really fun to do. Giving you 3 different base combat approaches, 4 special abilities that get throughout the game ("that uses an ability meter"), a grapple move with different add-ons, and 2 special movement abilities. That does not even include the other forms and their abilities. As you can see, there is a lot of variety in this game.

Cons
The more does not always mean the merrier, as a seasoned guacamelee player, you understand the moves how to use them, and the game can be pretty fun. But to a friend or sibling you are bringing in later to play, they become confused and overwhelmed with the amount of things you can do. The dimension swapping is used beautifully in platfroming segments, but not as well in combat. Some enemies cannot be attacked in one dimension, so you have to switch. That is good design, but the enemies can always attack you, regardless of dimension. Later in game, when they pile on multiple enemies from multiple dimensions, instead of getting challenging, it gets frustrating. This caused me to loathe any combat segment later in game. Also most bosses are very "cheap", with too much health and a very small window to attack them. But I've always felt that was the problem for most metroidvania bosses. When they are to weak, you breeze through and completely forget them. When they are too HARD (Final Boss), then it isn't fun. You are no longer a fighter against a very powerful foe, and you must learn their technique to win. You are waiting for them to attack, dodging, attack, waiting, dodging, attacking, losing, repeat, repeat, REPEAT. This wouldn't be so bad if it didn't happen that often, but later in game, bosses become harder, and more of them.

Best Parts of the game:
Abilities (you must learn them)
Enemies
Platforming segments
Graphics style
Music
Characters
Story
The Arena section

Worst Parts of game:
Bosses (most)
Enemies (Later in Game)
Difficult learning curve (if you come in later)

With so little Cons, you'd think I love the Game, and I do, but those few nagging details were so prevalent, especially in the last third of the game, that I can't recommend this game. I do love it, and I'm glad I bought it, but it  left me with such a sour taste that I cannot recommend it. If you can deal with those issues. Then buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138571692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1505164088}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038027462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1504303150}
review:
Very traditional in terms of gameplay at first, the switching world mecanic adds an interesting depth during combat and platforming. It might be underexploited for some people but since the game doesn't aim to be a puzzle game, I feel like they made the right choice. The game shines with its universe, respecting the cheerfulness of the Day of the Dead in Mexico. The soundtrack is good without being one of the greatest. The only weakness is the conventional plot.

I highly recommend the game, even if you're not into Metroidvania because the locations are very linear and getting to where you want is pretty easy.

review:

Sortie en 2015 sur toutes les plateformes actuelles, GuacamÃ©lÃ©e STCE est issu de la rencontre de plusieurs genres totalement diffÃ©rents que sont le Beat m'Up, le plateformer mais aussi et le plus curieux... Le Metroidvania !

L'histoire se concentre sur Juan Aguacate, un jeune paysan vivant paisiblement au beau milieu des champs qui un jour, pile au moment de la fameuse fÃªte des Morts au Mexique, va voir son destin totalement basculÃ© lorsqu'il va retrouver son amour d'enfance, la jeune fille del prÃ©sidente ! HÃ©las ! MalgrÃ© leurs retrouvailles, cette derniÃ¨re va se faire kidnappÃ© par un horrible personnage nommÃ© Calaca, un homme mi-mort/mi-humain qui va Ã©liminÃ© Juan devant les yeux de la jeune demoiselle... LaissÃ© pour mort et plongÃ© dans l'autre monde, Juan ferra la rencontre d'une mystÃ©rieuse luchador dÃ©nommÃ©e : Tostada qui va lui remettre un objet bien particulier... "le masque du luchador". Prenant son courage Ã  deux mains, Juan enfilera ce fameux masque et partira Ã  la rescousse de sa chÃ¨re et tendre !

Un air de dÃ©jÃ  vu ? Oui, cela reste encore une nouvelle fois le fameux hÃ©ros qui va sauver sa princesse, mais contrairement Ã  tous ses autres jeux, GuacamÃ©lÃ©e s'en moque totalement et joue justement sur ce clichÃ© pour proposer une histoire originale totalement barrÃ©e avec des personnages secondaires uniques en leur genre. Les dialogues sont mÃªme Ã  mourir de rire par moment et font d'ailleurs d'Ã©normes clins d'oeil soit au jeu vidÃ©o en gÃ©nÃ©ral ou bien carrÃ©ment Ã  la pop culture. Vous allez me dire, comment Beat m'up et Metroidvania peuvent-il cohabitÃ© ? Et bien, c'est trÃ¨s simple ! GuacamÃ©lÃ©e se joue de long en large comme un Metroidvania, le joueur peut avancer dans des niveaux ouverts ou tous les chemins sont possibles pour avancer Ã  condition d'avoir les bonnes capacitÃ©s ou Ã©vÃ©nements activÃ©s. De plus au cours de l'aventure, le joueur aura aussi la possibilitÃ© d'acquÃ©rir des techniques spÃ©ciaux pour pouvoir Ã  la fois dÃ©truire ses adversaires de faÃ§on spectaculaire, mais aussi, et comme dans tout Metroidvania, passÃ© certains passages complexes pour pourvoir dÃ©bloquÃ© de nouvelles routes qui Ã©tait alors inaccessibles sans cette derniÃ¨re.

Et c'est la qu'on se rend compte que le Beat m'up et le Metroidvania peuvent Ãªtre compatible ! car certes on se bastonne face Ã  des hordes et des hordes d'ennemies, mais cela reste dans des environnements ouverts ou le joueur peut accÃ©dÃ© Ã  plusieurs chemins possibles et/ou trouver des passages secrets permettant de rÃ©cupÃ©rer des upgrades pour Juan !

Bref vous l'aurez compris, c'est un Gameplay au petit oignon et vÃ©ritablement fun ! Il y a vraiment de bonnes idÃ©es partout et on ne se lasse pas un instant du jeu. Surtout qu'en plus le jeu est mÃªme jouable Ã  4 simultanÃ©ment, ce qui nous rÃ©serve des heures de fun en COOP. En plus d'avoir un Gameplay des plus corrects, GuacamÃ©lÃ©e peut se vanter par sa rÃ©alisation technique fantastique qui envoie vÃ©ritablement du rÃªve ! author: {'steamid': '76561198028857023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1503617051}
review:
A fun Metroidvania style beat em up. 8/10 if bought on sale.

PROS:
-Solid platforming and combat
-Four player local coop
-Fun art style
-Good humor

Cons:
-A bit short for the price tag 
-Gameplay is broken up by frequent, unskippable dialogue. Especially tedious on subsequent playthroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146663055', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1314, 'last_played': 1685081274}
review:
[h1]INTRODUCCIÃ“N[/h1]
Guacamelee! es un Juego de plataformas de la categorÃ­a "Metroidvania", llamado asi porque toma el sistema de plataformas de Metroid y el combate de Castelvania, mezclandolos para asÃ­ patentar su estilo de juego. El juego se ambienta en la Cultura Mexicana, y nos cuenta la Historia de Juan, un Hombre que se dedica al destilamiento de Tequila en su Pueblucho, hasta que el proclamado rey del mundo de los muertos; Carlos Calaca, desea fusionar ambos mundos, el de los vivos y los muertos, para asi ser el mÃ¡ximo gobernante, Juan impulsado por el secuestro de Su amada, se embarca en una aventura para detener a Calaca, con la ayuda de la legendaria mÃ¡scara del luchador, y la guardiana de la Misma, Tostada.

[h1]PRESENTACIÃ“N[/h1]
El juego es presentado con una estÃ©tica "Flat", es decir diseÃ±o plano, y hay que admitir que se ve simplemente hermoso, estÃ¡ bien pulido, es colorido, es dinamico, y los personajes son reconocibles, se ven muy bien, y se mueven acorde a su diseÃ±o. A esto se le suma la espectacular estetica basada en MÃ©xico, Detalles como los fondos, las paletas de colores, los acabados de objetos como casas, templos, pueblos, ciudades, valles, estatuas, simplemente el juego grita a viva voz (En el ambito de diseÃ±o) "VIVA MÃ‰XICO", describirlo en texto no basta, debes verlo con us propios ojos. Entre otras cosas el presentar una historia basada en la que quizas es la festividad mas importante de MÃ©xico, el dia de los Muertos, le da un plus bastante alto, algo clichÃ© tal vez, pero bien ejecutado, se hacen referencias a la festividad, por ejemplo [spoiler]Los puntos de guardado, que asi mismo son la tienda, son las muy reonocidas Calaveritas de Azucar en un pequeÃ±o altar[/spoiler], es una bonita referencia a la festividad, y no es la Ãºnica hay muchas mas, y no solo eso, el juego todo el tiempo Hace referencias a otras franquisias, juegos e incluso Memes de Internet, y darse cuenta de las mismas te puede sacar una sonrisa, son detalles pequeÃ±os que alegran tu experiencia de juego, y que te impulsan a encontrar mas. Oh y la Banda sonora... Es simplemente exelente, el juego implementa los intrumentos tradicionales MÃ©xicanos, y se denotan generos como la Balada suave y la Serenata, y en partes en las que hay bastante acciÃ³n, como areas de exploraciÃ³n y combate, la mÃºsica se ajusta a la misma, mientras que en areas como ciudades o pueblos la mÃºsica es serena y tranquila, muy bien ejecutada, es buena hasta el punto en que no te cansas de oirla.

[h1]JUGABILIDAD[/h1]
Guacamelee! Esta plenamente y obviamente inspirado en Juegos como Castelvania Symphony of the Nigth, y Super Metroid (Hasta su descripciÃ³n en la tienda lo Menciona), aparte tiene un sistema de combos en el cual puedes encadenar varios ataques y luego agarrar a tu enemigo para lanzarlo o darle un golpe de gracia, esto estÃ¡ muy bien establecido, es un sistema de combate divertido, facil de aprender, y funciona muy bien incluso si hay ordas de enemigos. Ademas cabe mencionar que desde su ultima actualizaciÃ³n, el juego se puede jugar hasta con 4 prsonas en pantalla (Antes esto estaba limitado a solo 2 Jugadores), lo cual da para una muy buena experiencia en multijugador, ya que entre todos se puede planear una estrategia para derrotar a enemigos mas facilmente o completar el juego mas rÃ¡pido, bastante [spoiler]INTENSO![/spoiler]

[h1]VEREDICTO[/h1]
[b]8.5/10 - BUENISIMO[/b] Â¿Vale La Pena?, Vale Cada **** Peso. AHORA COMPRALO GÃœEY!.
Vale la pena, definitivamente lo vale. Guacamelee! es basicamente una carta de amor al genero de las plataformas, un juego divertido, visualmente hermoso, entretenido, con una historia muy bien estructurada, y personajes carismaticos.
Tiene una cantidad justa de logros, y una duraciÃ³n justificable y visto y considerando que el juego tiene [spoiler]Mas de un Final[/spoiler] Vale la pena experimentarlo y saber en que termina la historia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077987889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1506939688}
review: I can count with my hands how many platformers I've played, never played a metroidvania game, so this was an absolute spicy treat. The puzzle elements this game throws at you are intriguing and frustrating at times but you feel great once you figured it out( at lest I did anyways). The combat is a blast, I loved the variety of powerups you recieved and how you can go back to older areas and unlock new paths. Which is where I had an issue, the backtracking can be a pain, even with the insta-teleport system, it's not that terrible just a slight issue I had. The variety of pop culture refrenences are hilarious and quite fun to spot. The characters are charming and add life to Guacamelee, the music is composed with it culture and adds more depth to this game, the slight changes to environment and music when you are in the land of the dead is very detailed. Took me 8hrs to beat this fantastic game. I got Guacameele for $4 which was a steal, buy this game whenever you see it for sale it's definitely worth the pickup.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973084271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1503790288}
review:
WOW THIS IS FABULOUS. Bright colors, techno mariachi music, and beautiful, BEAUTIFUL 2D platformer handling. And sometimes I get to be a chicken. It is everything I didn't know I wanted in a Metroidvania. 

Before I bought it, I thought this was a go-to-the-right-beat-em-up like the arcade version of TMNT or THE SIMPSONS. But then it came up during a lookup of Metroidvanias and I had a closer look. I still wasn't quite sure if it was the game for me. THEN there was a sale--get the Super Turbo Championship Edition, Gold Edition, AND soundtrack for $6. I couldn't pass up the deal.

Since the Super Turbo version looked to be the more "complete" version of the game, I deleted the Gold version and started my GUACAMELEE journey.

This game does a ton of things right. Checkpoints are generous. The beat 'em up sections are fun to complete, even when playing on a keyboard. Miss a platform jump (in a series of them over water), and instead of going back to a last checkpoint, you go to the last bit of solid ground you stood on. THANK YOU, GUACAMELEE, FOR RESPECTING MY TIME.

I groused at first about the lack of double-jump, but in the end, I was glad they made me use the Rooster Punch so often, because then I discovered its versatility. Then when I did get double jump, I found myself using it differently. 

Within hours, I was zipping across the neon landscape like a champ, goat-jumping off walls while switching dimensions and punching skeletons in the face like a stud. THAT'S what I play platformers for.

The abilities upgrade system is a little weak -- at times it was hard to see how spending pesos improved said abilities--

As a kid, I fell in love with Castlevania: Symphony of the Night for its dark-yet-fun horror-gothic vibe. I grew up with the Donkey Kong Country games. I've played nearly all the Nifflas platformers, which have a chill mystique. GUACAMELEE has the wonderful quality of movement of ALL those games PLUS a zesty feast for your eyes and ears, the most festive, fun platformer I've played in a L O N G time. 

Come for the platforming, stay for the art. And chicken.

review: Have you ever wanted to be a luchador who pulls off crazy super moves and punch skeletons in the face? Do you want to become a chicken and lay eggs that explode? Do you think you're a bad enough hombre to rescue El Presidente's daughter? Then this is the game for you!

review: I love Metroidvanias, I love the aesthetic of this game, and I love that the Devil grants you the power to turn into a chicken.  I don't know how I feel about the large open spaces of the map, but I still really enjoyed the game.  The core plot is also pretty boring, with a by-the-book "save your 'childhood friend' from an evil magical dude who turns into something really huge" plot and an ending where one of the main characters dies that changes depending on whether you got all of a collectible, but the details and backstory were pretty entertaining.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089943640', 'num_games_owned': 1438, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1251, 'last_played': 1500270049}
review:
I 100% completed this game in 20.9 Hours. Story mode can take about 4-7 hours without completionisting.

A metroidvania beat em up? Sign me up! A wonderfully fun game that anyone will love. The levels are wonderfully designed and the music works perfectly for each place even though it does get repetitive after 10 hours. Any challenges are always fair and will test you on what the game has taught you while you play. Spamming is not an option here.

Completionists will have a decent time here. Nothing is hard to achieve it just takes a ton of time to finish it. Prepair to collect everything by passing puzzles that'll test you on your knowledge of the game. You'll also have to play through the game twice for the hard mode. So just be patient and you'll complete this in no time. Good luck!

I recommend this game at any price if you plan on 100% it. Maybe a bit cheaper if you want to just play through quick which is a bad idea.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989188746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1496616057}
review: I had never heard of Guacamelee until I received it in a Humble Bundle, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a solid Metroidvania with satisfying combat, a lot of interesting abilities, and a big, varied map. The tone is silly and lighthearted, and falls short of funny, but also didn't get annoying, which is a real danger in comedy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048008412', 'num_games_owned': 489, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1590285758}
review:
I personally don't really enjoy most of the metroidvania type game that I've played, but loved Guacamelee.
It's fast paced, light hearted, and quite fun.
The game has heavy Mexican/Mesoamerican (and a little Incan) influences, ranging from the mythical to steryotypical, but never get too out of hand. The game also is willing to make jokes about typical game mechanics and make some refrences, but again doesn't go overboard with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971039128', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1499129728}
review:
This game is splendid.  It's a solid brawler with Metroidvania influences, with the latter influences being implemented tastefully as to not waste the player's time with tons of backtracking (a common complaint in other Metroid-influenced games).

The music is fantastic, and the humor tongue-in-cheek.  I was surprised this was made by a bunch of Canadians as the subject matter, while funny, is a little bit casually-racist.  Didn't bother me at all, but I could see it being a barriers to others.

I would definitely recommend playing this with a controller, as all 2D platformer games.  With that said, controls are nice and tight , though I recommend using the D-pad over the Thumbstick as the combos definitely benefit from that precision.

All in all, this comes recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038830259', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 2175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1499604927}
review:
Overall this game is really good

The colors, the art direction, everything about it screams mexico in the best way

every detail in this game I like, from the houses having different people in dead/alive mode, I like the music and how it changes so easily.

And of course the combat is the best part, its fluent, fun, and fast, and if you like to combo, god damn this game has a combo chicken just for.

the only issues are that at time the requirment for combos can be annoying, by the end of the game you feel sick and tired of skeletons in every aspect, and the fact that there is no ng+ for people to explore after they have beaten it.

this is honestly a super fun, detailed expereince, that when you play you can FEEL the passion in every corner of this game, well done to the devs for staying so true to mexican culture with this game and creating one of the most colorful and fun worlds I have ever seen.

Would 100% pick up and play, I mean it 15 dollars you gotta give it a shot, and if its on sale GET THIS SPICY DEAL.

review:
Amazing visuals and concept.
Worst controls I've ever experienced in a platformer.
Certain bosses force you to cheese the game instead of playing it properly.
Extremely frustrating at times, utterly impossible without borderline cheating at others.
Really dropped the ball on the grapple mechanic, it's pretty much useless.
Surprisingly linear for a metroidvania.
Skip it and get something worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040842672', 'num_games_owned': 3000, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1498767364}
review:
Guacamelee! is a action platformer with combo-based melee combat and exploration elements. You play as Juan, a farmer who gains superpowers after finding a mysterious luchador mask. You fight through throngs of enemies in a Mexican-inspired setting on your quest to rescue El Presidente's kidnapped daughter.

Super Turbo Championship Edition is rather pointless (and frankly greedy) rerelease of the game with rebalanced encounters, some new content and a poorly implemented new mechanic. In hindsight I should have just played the earlier Gold Edition instead of buying this one. Rather annoyingly there's no discount anymore for upgrading from the Gold Edition and you have to pay the full price for this one even if you own the earlier release .

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The game has a strong visual style that fits the theme well. Unfortunately the visuals leave a lot to be desired on a technical level. A lot of the artwork is rather poorly done and the animations in particular are terrible. Also, the game does not properly support 16:10 resolutions.

The game also suffers from rather heavy tearing on my system. Enabling vsync will fix the issue but leads to nearly unplayable controller lag.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The sound effects are decent enough although there seemed to be issues with the timings of some sounds. The music is well done if rather repetitive and fits the theme well. There's no real voice acting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game plays like a fairly typical metroidvania with combo-based melee combat. You explore the maps and unlock special powers that let you progress to new areas. These powers are pretty standard from wall climbing and double jumping to various attack moves that let you break through special color-coded walls.

You also gain the power to switch between the land of the dead and the land of the living, although nothing particularly inventive is done with this ability. In practice it's mainly used for a lot of rather repetitive and tedious platforming sections.

My early impressions of the combat were quite positive. Chaining the combos is fun and the combat flows quite well. Unfortunately as you progress the game keeps adding more and more gimmicky elements that mess up the core gameplay. Having to constantly break enemy shields and switch between the land of the dead/living just breaks the flow and makes the combat lot less enjoyable.

Way too much of the combat also takes place in small closed-off arenas. I certainly felt that this was a rather baffling design choice in a metroidvania game and would have preferred more open-ended encounters.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
I found the game pretty easy on normal difficulty, although this will be heavily dependant on your ability to pull of combos and your platforming skills. The final area is certainly a big step up in difficulty and some of the optional puzzles and areas are quite a bit harder too.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls are pretty solid on a gamepad. Some moves can feel slightly imprecise, however.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The story is very basic and clichÃ©. The writing is pretty terrible too and the jokes in particular are extremely cringeworthy. I felt that much more could have been done with the Mexican theme.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
Overall the game is fairly polished and I didn't encounter any major bugs.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Personally I found Guacamelee! a somewhat disappointing game. The core gameplay is solid enough, but the game introduces way too many poorly implemented powers and gimmicky enemies that end up making the combat lot less fun. The writing is pretty terrible too and the exploration aspects are not particularly satisfying. It's not a terrible game by any means, but I still didn't find it enjoyable enough to recommend.

It took me little under 6 hours to play through the game on normal. I didn't bother with most optional areas, just completed the main story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998648357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1498423981}
review:
Really fun and challenging metroidvania in a Mexican setting with luchadores, chupacabras, demons and chickens!

Art style is really good, music too, and there is a lot of humor and easter eggs referencing other games and memes which makes it more funny. Some of the power ups really remind me Metroid games, and the combats are like a Beat Them All or fighthing game (lots of combos).

There is an extra ending and lots of special challenges for extra replay value!

PS: buy the Super Turbo Championship Edition which is more complete (new powers, new levels, ...) than the Gold Edition. Also, as far as I know, Gold Edition save games are not transferable to STCE.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969054179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1497232839}
review:
I really wish there was a middle-ground between thumbs-up and thumbs-down, because that's what I would choose.

The good: this game has a gorgeous art style, a lot of humor, and is overall a pretty fun platformer.

The bad: the game focuses more and more on being able to pull off combos as you progress, which is something I hate. I reached a point where I just couldn't proceed because I don't have the physical and/or mental dexterity to pull off the exact correct button combinations at the exact correct times. That's just not fun gameplay.
