author: {'steamid': '76561198059896926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1421558303}
review:
A suprisingly excellent metroid-vania style platformer/beat-em-up. It utelizes the wrestling moves so that not only are you using them to defeat enemies and open doors, but they're also incorporated into the platforming as well. 
Just know that this game is packed full of aging memes and references that may make you cringe a bit. Though the huge workshop support may remedy that for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020097921', 'num_games_owned': 684, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1053, 'last_played': 1437542727}
review:
Pros:
-You're a Luchador
-Easter Eggs... tons of Easter Eggs
-Easy to understand mechanics
-Story isn't too deep, very linear and a wee bit predictable, but you will get immersed (well I did) and you will still get some feels.
-You're a fucking Luchador!

Cons:
-Unforgiving, like a good old 80-90's game: a few (or one) false move can destroy you or impede your progress - luckily this is still a modern day game, so they threw you a bone: infinite lives - when you die: you respawn at a checkpoint, your progress beyond the checkpoint is lost, but that's it. no "X4 lives left". -whew.
-Uncomfortable key mappings (this is for gamepad) that cannot be changed. Paired with the former cons, this makes the game more frustrating than it should.

9/10; not giving 'em a 10 not untill they fix the controller problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012706915', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1423963353}
review:
I don't usually like side scrolling platformers too much (I tend to get bored of them easily) but for some reason the moment I started this game I was totally hooked.  I think it must be because I just like throwing things into other things constantly...

The combat was really great with lots of different combos to learn and the mechanics of grappling and throwing an enemy around was just really ridiculously satisfying for some reason.  The choice of outfits made things interesting too as the effects really made a difference (and I liked that one turned you into a dragon instead of a chicken!).  I also really loved the challenges and the secret rooms and the one I like to call the troll room because it was so ridiculously difficult!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056092379', 'num_games_owned': 887, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1629249739}
review:
I'm on the fence about this version of the game, but I am leaning toward a yes. Be noted, this game is just Guacamelee 1.5. The fact that I had to repurchase a game I owned felt like it cheated me, but luckily I got it on sale from HumbleBundle.

Pros:
Great game
Steam Workshop
New additions
Metroidvania games are always fun
Controller support is easy

Cons:
Steep price for users that own the original.
Gold version runs on Linux, yet this one doesn't. What's up with that?

author: {'steamid': '76561198011498752', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1687982029}
review:
This is the definitive version of the game, do not get the gold edition. If already bought gold though, you may safely skip this one, as there are only some minor additions that do not really warrant another purchase.

This game has:
- a great soundtrack 
- a great artstyle and overall theme
- a slightly campy sort of humour
- a very satisfying combat system
- a shortish campaign (about 5~6 hours on the first playthrough), but with decent incentives for repeat playthroughs

In short: definitely worth a purchase if you haven't played the game yet, and pretty much a must buy during sales.

review: Not bad, if you like platformer and beat-em-up you're going to like this game. Pretty graphics and the combo tricks is fun yet challenging to master. This is no mindless insane killing like Expendabros though, it's more like Rayman. I guess. I kind of mistook it for the former. The only downside for me is that though the game is moddable, there is only a few mods available and not much to mod besides the skin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040914294', 'num_games_owned': 744, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1687574940}
review:
If you are new to Guacamelee! in general, look further down for a general review. Following is a comparison of versions.

When I first saw this, I thought it was a moneygrab. It is absolutely not. The Super Turbo Championchip Edition improves so much on Gold Edition that they are almost incomperable. The most notable additions are:
- The chicken bomb
- Rebalancing of the enemies in just about every area and stat rebalancing of enemies
- The fighting system got rebuffed and everything feels much, much smoother
- A new 'super' type mode you can initiate after doing lots of combos
- New story additions and a new boss
All in all, the game feels much fuller.

Now for a general review of Guacamelee!
Guacamelee! is a metroidvania that really knows how to mix its genres. While the basic mechanics of platforming and fighting are both there, the fighting has a good amount of depth to it without becoming overly complex. After playing for a while, combos seemlessly stream out into an arena of destruction... and it feels really good. In Guacamelee! I can punch and upper cut an enemy into the air, headbut them, body slam them, and then grab them to suplex them into the ground to knock other enemies off balance only to start another combo. And it doesn't require dozens of hours to learn. On top of the fighting system, there are many, many upgrades to find and buy. Search a large world for upgrades, find the good ending, complete some challenges, unlock some sweet costumes, turn into a chicken! Okay, that last one was a little different than the rest, but you get the idea.

TL;DR
Guacamelee! STCE is the best edition. The game is a metroidvania with more depth to fighting. Lots of upgrades. Chickens. Worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133628702', 'num_games_owned': 2145, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1570231679}
review:
I just finished this game on co-op and I gotta say it's some of the most fun I've had in a long time. It took us about 7 hours to beat even with the two of us. You pretty much play as a super-hero luchador in a beat-em-up style game trying to save your princess. There is tons of secrets, in which you don't unlock the 'true ending' unless you find them all. You can also unlock different costumes which gives you different benefits and you can upgrade your skills. I played most of the game with the Diablo suit which kind of made it like hard mode even on easy.

I gotta say this game really did remind me of the old-school games and some of the music even sounded alot like Mario and other games. Enemies were decently hard to beat without being too difficult, but keep in mind I did have another player helping me. Storyline is decent and there is tons of humor in the game also. It's kinda like they took everything people love about indie games and put it into this game.

Co-op design is fairly decent but the camera kinda sucks as it will only follow player one instead of expanding. Every time you die you have a timer to wait to come back and when you do you're a little orb that floats around until your teammate releases you. I felt this made the co-op fair without being too much struggle. Pretty much a fun co-op experience that adds mild difficulty to great teamwork gameplay. Coordinating certain platforming can be incredibly hectic though and we usually just let one person do all the platforming at the hard parts because it was too hard with two people to do.

Co-op is also somewhat buggy... I have a screenshot where instead of dying, me and my buddy just have 3 copies of ourselves each...

I will probably replay the hell out of this game until I unlock all of the achievements. I can't really say too much bad about the game in all honestly so I would have to give the game somewhere around a 4.5/5.

review:
(Apologies if I have bad grammar)
GET THIS F***ING GAME AND PLAY IT. 
No, really, you should play it, it has everything that a game should have:
-Funny plot with enjoyable characters and a ton of memes and easter eggs? Check
-Awesome combos and moments that challenge your skills? Check
-BE A FREAKING CHICKEN THAT CAN LAY EXPLOSIVE EGGS?!?!!?!? BET YOUR SWEATY ASS CHECK
The game is quite short to be honest, but SWEET HOLY MOTHER OF GUACAMOLE AND NACHOS YOU CAN PLAY AS FREAKING BAYONETTA AND THE MONOLITH OF 2001 SPACE ODISSEY?!??!?! HELL YEAH, thanks to the amazing workshop page.
Yes, I love this game. Yes, you should buy it. And yes, I'll stop writing.
Score: An enchilada/10

review:
This is an enhanced version of Guacamelee! Gold Edition, itself being an upgrade of Guacamelee!
I'd say that the additions in STCE from Gold are OK, if you haven't played any, buy STCE and enjoy. If you've already played another version, then maybe you should keep your money.

Here I've pasted the review i wrote on Gold Edition, which is still relevant as everything that was great is still great


Posted: 22 Feb, 2014 @ 11:23pm	
Updated: 22 Feb, 2014 @ 11:25pm

This game is really enjoyable: Gameplay is simple, Graphics are colorful, not very long but cheap though... You'll also see a LOT of easter eggs, and if you like the video game universe, you'll be like a child in a park!
Buy it when on sale or not, you'll have fun times playing El Juan del populo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055553431', 'num_games_owned': 7573, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1506008737}
review:
[h1] Pueblucho si arricchisce di 2 aree nuove, di un'ottima boss fight e di un combat system ancora piÃ¹ vario.
E' ancora teatrale, con un level design eccezionale, nella sua doppia anima frizzante e malinconica. [/h1]

Ho giocato principalmente alla versione gold edition; questa Ã¨ una revisione completa dei contenuti aggiuntivi. Ci regala qualche ora e qualche colorato abito in piÃ¹, per il resto vale quanto giÃ  lodato nella versione precedente.

Molto colorato, con una doppia anima artistica molto ispirata; DrinkBox ci regala un doppio mondo di gioco in rapida evoluzione con un crescendo di abilitÃ , umorismo e zone da scoprire condito da un sano backtracking.
Raramente si riesce ad avere in un solo prodotto 1 storia narrata in maniera interessante, un combat system profondo, un level design eccezionale in grado di esaltare un gameplay a tratti sorprendentemente tecnico e un ritmo crescente cosÃ¬ ben curati.

Un intrecciato mondo da scoprire grazie ad una maschera; un inno a titoli ricchi di atmosfera e magia come Super Mario e Metroid, le cui statue di Choozo richiamano chiaramente l'antica razza aliena dal volto rapace dei Chozo di Zebes, che creÃ² i Metroid.

L'aggiunta della co-op locale Ã¨ una funzione gradita e troppo spesso dimenticata in produzioni moderne; se avete un/a complice con cui condividere lo schermo troverete questa opzione molto soddisfacente...se sarete affiatati! Si perchÃ¨ in alcune zone la sincronizzazione dei movimenti tra i 2 mondi e tra i 2 giocatori sarÃ  fondamentale per proseguire il livello.

Un saggio-capra vi guiderÃ  dunque in questa telenovela in salsa messicana, in cui dovremo ovviamente salvare la principessa dal cattivone di turno oltre a tramutarci di tanto in tanto in pollo...ma la banalitÃ  non fa parte di Pueblucho, qui dimorano citazioni, modi di dire, tabelloni magistralmente dipinti con la passione tipicamente latina.

Ottimo il doppiaggio e il comparto tecnico con comandi sempre precisi in grado di approfondire le meccaniche senza lag. Semplicemente sorprendente il sonoro, con una tracklist travolgente in piena anima messicana.

Se non ci fossero stati livelli a volte troppo sbilanciati con alcuni enigmi mal calibrati saremmo di fronte ad un titolo quasi perfetto. Qualcuno lo eleverÃ  a capolavoro, di sicuro Ã¨ un indie di grande personalitÃ  che non ha paura di essere confrontato con le produzioni tripla A.

[h1]Extra[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198159129085', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1427522830}
review:
"Guacamelee!" is about a simple man turned luchadore at the face of supernatural shenanigans. 
You wanna be mucho caliente, ese? Play this game. It'll make you feel pretty badass.
"Guacamelee!" is definitely a game worth playing for fans of beat 'em ups.
Upgrades are satisfying and the costumes' status effects are pretty varied.
Level design is beautifully simple, with matching music for every location.
The dialogue is actually pretty funny, to contrast with the semi-serious plot.

I'd personally give this game a 7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197962245021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1515386065}
review:
The game is really fun and gorgeous. It's very colorful, and the music is nice, too.

It warns you when you boot it up that the game is best played with a controller. I'm not sure if using a controller would fix this problem, but I have been using the keyboard and it can sometimes be difficult to execute moves, specifically the uppercut. This can be frustrating at times, as you're often required to use the uppercut in combination with other jumps to reach high places/execute combos. Other than that, the game is a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044691652', 'num_games_owned': 1020, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1479934094}
review:
My recommendation for this game:

COMPLETELY ABSOLUTELY VERILY YES!!!

Get it.
It's unique.
It's well crafted.
It will teach you stuff on the way. And very forgiving for the most part.
Controls are tight and you don't need to worry about fiddly widdly things.

Best part of the game is its culturally immersive setting. I'm not a Native Mexican in any way. And this whole game provided a whole lot of newness to me.

Live in the Americas? No problem! Still plenty enjoyable for its awesome gameplay alone.

Think about it.

You start out as a burly guy, then a strong luchador, then you become...

LUCHAGOD!

By the time you get to the end of the game you will feel awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109860236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1429126659}
review:
The definitive edition in many ways....4 player co-op, improved visual effects, 2 new areas, a new boss, new enemies, "Intenso" mode, chicken bombs and redesigned progression through the map amongst the notable additions but as a gamer that has 100% both console and PC versions of Guacamelee Gold and Guacamelee STCE there's that nagging feeling that in nerfing Tule Tree, Caverna del Pollo and the bosses for example they took away most of the challenge and what were the more ambitious, more rewarding areas of the game. 

El Infierno remains a reasonable slog.

The game itself is still one of the most polished, accessible and fun Metroidvania games available, remaster or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012047568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1429122903}
review: One of the best action-platformers I have ever played. Though there were some moments where the game felt very fustrating in difficulty, I always came back to it, and felt satisfied or accomplished upon completing the challenging bosses or segment of a level. Its challending, but always fun and creative.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993154641', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1425180007}
review: One of the best games I've played in a while. If you enjoy Metroidvania style games, this is a perfectly executed example. Combat feels great and the visual style is uniquely appealing. A quick note that there's not much point in purchasing both the Gold and Super Turbo Championship editions. Just purchase the latter as it has everything that Gold has with some gameplay and graphical improvements, plus an additional area to explore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100992838', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1504, 'last_played': 1428979383}
review:
When put in comparison to the Gold Edition, you would expect this game to be better. It is... but at the same time it's not. It features more content, but half the achievements are gone, and what is added isn't really that much of a difference in the first place,and could've simply been a DLC.

That being said, the visuals are really something to be seen, the soundtrack is good (and even more so when you notice the small differences when you swap worlds), the gameplay is tight, and it feels consistent... Until the bright colors get old fast, and the game will play a cheap trick and force you to play the game again to get a single achievement because it doesn't let you choose hard mode from the get go.

Speaking of the hard mode, the only real difference I felt was in X'tabay and Javier Jaguar fights. And boy, let me tell you , Javier was NOT ballanced at all. His dodging feels like the game is cheating you and the white barrier is absolutely cheap, when it regenerates and he will just dodge and swap worlds, or use his aura to blast you away.

With all that said, the game is still recommended. I just had a few bones to pick with it. It's not THAT hard, but something might not be enjoyable if you're trying to look for a game to complete. However, yes, this is a game that must be played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048638362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1428880243}
review: A game that will have you running into puzzles and combat believing them impossible to accomplish but after a few tries leaves you praising the devs for their creative level design.  Satsifying combat supports this with a full range of moves to not only navigate the world but take down anyone in your path.  Worth playing even if not a big fan of platformers or indie games, cant wait for a sequel or more games made by these devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046589425', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1423926182}
review:
This is going to be my first negative review, and i feel so bad for giving a thumbs down for a gorgeous game like " Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition ".

I was looking for so much in this game, but i guess looks can be decieving.

It has great art, its a gorgeous game, great ambiance, and decent mechanics.

But the game itself, is so so slow, it takes a while for you to be able to do anything, it also takes a while for you to progress in the story, and will take even more time for you to understand where you're supposed to go. 

You're in a game where everything is colorfull and saturated and you want to do so much and kill people and kick ass but no, you'll walk. God you [b]WILL WALK SO MUCH[/b] you walk so much you spend hours trying to get past a map and you find yourself in a dead end and that makes you go all the way back to where you started. 

I just get that " ohh goddddddd this again. Sighs, i guess i'll just walk there again " vibe everytime i play it. At _least_ the game is pretty. meh i just expected way more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046001968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1421573300}
review: Had tons of fun playing this game. That metroidvania feel to it is just beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960517920', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1417107897}
review:
The Metroidvania game we've been waiting for.

Very fun brawler-style combat, lots of secrets to uncover, powerups are pretty awesome (wuzzup chi-cken how you doin), and the music/atmosphere is top-notch. Animation is gorgeous.

AND IT HAS LOCAL COOP. Shame about no online multi, but for a game like this, it would've been a bonus.

Besides the added content in the STCE, obtaining new powerups now boast 95% non-seizure-inducing backgrounds! This is a huge step up from the base game, since grabbing new powers meant a trip to the neurosurgeon!

Pollos/10, one of the best Metroidvanias in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124869455', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1430478803}
review:
Guacamelee is one of the best platformers I played lately. 
Is the first game that my girlfriend also enjoyed playing so we get to play it co-op(probably because she can pick the female character and she also gets to dress her). 
- also, it can be played up to 4 players co-op(which probably is too much for 1 screen)

I have to say it's far more complex and has a lot more content than what I thought when I got it: you can change dimensions, transform in a chicken(to fit through narrow places) and you have enough skills to play around with. Also you can buy upgrades or new costumes that each has benefits and drawbacks.

What I like:
- the graphics
- storyline is funny
- lot of content(10h+ of gameplay(played some offline) and it seems we're only halfway)
- some rounds require a little "puzzle solving"
- various enemies and also boss levels are cool
- you can become a chicken

What I don't like:
- Some levels require maybe too much button mashing, and you have to retry lots of times until you get it perfect
- When playing local co-op, the screen follows player one(which seems normal) but lots of times even if player2 manages to cross some intricate button mashing section it will be returned back to player1's location. While if player1 succesfully passes an area, player2 will be again automatically teleported to player1 so he doesn't have to do it also. So lots of times the levels that require perfect combos to pass them are only dependend on player1(if he passes, all pass. If he doesn't noone pass)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998497020', 'num_games_owned': 558, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1450542965}
review:
An absolute platforming blast. Gold edition was fantastic and even if you have beaten it I still would reccomend super turbo championship edition. It just tightens everything up; expands the story, allows for 4-person local co-op, adds egg bombs... it's just so much fun to play, especially with friends. This game has actual skill requirements for its platforming puzzles and that is where the only flaw I can imagine for this game comes from (though completely avoidable in this version with moderate skill): co-operative platforming often results in getting in eachother's way.

In gold edition everybody was locked to the same phase as eachother meaning that platform puzzles that involved phase swaps got complicated, nigh impossible, fast. IN this one everybody can control their phase independantly, which makes it completely plausible, just confusing. When we played through we usually dropped to one player for difficult puzzles to keep camera in the best location.

Overall I loved this game, my absolute favourite platformer thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141057220', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1441562285}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019266495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1426620545}
review:
It is with a heavy heart and a headache that I review this game. I have given it MANY times to try to save itself, but, now, at the last temple, it still fails. This game had a lot of potential, it really did. Smooth gameplay, nice combat system, funny story. But what it can't do, is be fun. The battles get so hard you can't get past areas, and with no difficulty settings, unless you are a major league, play hours a day, button mashing person, you will NEVER get to the end of this. 
For me? I am just going to watch a lets play of the last 20 minutes of the game, becaus I am done screaming at the game as it throws waves of baddies at you that stun lock you from full health to nothing in a matter of three seconds. 
Only get this game if you really want a hard time, for me? I got many other games to go play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981557797', 'num_games_owned': 5234, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1424547375}
review: Awesome metroidvania game.  It has more challenging combat and platforming in comparison to other games in the genre; but it's never feels unfair.  The game references and humor sprinkled throughout the game also set a great tone for the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059130731', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1138, 'last_played': 1462485057}
review:
Last year I played and finished this game in co-op with a friend. It's one of the more satisfying things I played, plus a lot of simple good humor (specially when I speak mainly spanish).

The base game (and it's Gold Edition) is a great beat 'em up platformer with nice challenge in both aspects, but the fact of adding an INTENSO! meter and the possibility of playing this with 2 more friends is awesome. kinda remembered a coin-up arcade back in late 80s. Also, the Metroid-like exploring part is great too. I didn't had any problem at all revisiting areas looking to get that 100% on the area map. Some of the platforming to get some items is quite serious (damn you, Tule tree...), but it is not totally impossible.

If you enjoyed hardcore BTUs and platformers, you might want to give this a chance.

Guacamelee! Gold Edition is great, but this is the SUPER TURBO CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION. You have to get this one instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058456859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1556, 'last_played': 1422826846}
review:
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition!!!!!!

Guacamelee! Gold Edition war/ist schon super gewesen.
"Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition" ist noch um einiges Besser, es kommt aufplolierter und mit frischen Texturen daher und hat auch einige neue Gegener und Levels und Bosse parat.
Und die Gegener haben nun eine Lebensanzeige, diese gab es in der Gold Version nicht.
"Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition" kann mit insgesamt 4 Leuten im Lokalen Ko-op Modus gespielt werden.

Story:
Worum geht es in "Guacamelee!" ?
Dies ist schnell beantwortet, BÃ¶ser Arschloch-Kerl entfÃ¼hrt Freundin vom Helden, dieser Held versucht Freundin zu retten, kennen wir alles schon, ja ja. . .
Egal, dennoch ist die Geschichte und das ganze Setting in sich komplett schlÃ¼ssig und macht Spass es zu spielen.

Levels / Umgebung:
Die Levels (Dungeons) machen Spass und fordern, hier und da fehlt etwas Abwechslung, aber dies ist jammern auf hohem Niveau.

Was mich auch sehr gefreut hat sind die ganzen Verweise und Gags (Easter-Eggs) auf andere Video-Spiele. 
So gibt es etliche Plakte mit unteranderem "Link" oder den "Castle Crahsern" oder der "Kaktor" steht in der WÃ¼ste als Statue rum.


Alles in allem hat mich "Guacamelee! Gold Edition" + "Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition" vom ersten Augenblick an umgehauen und Ã¼berzeugt und ist eines meiner Lielbingsspiele geworden.


Kann jedem dieses Spiel nur empfehlen.
10 von 10 Punkten. 
Definitv.
Kaufen.
JETZT!
Und
Spielen. !!!

review:

The story has humor, it has workshop integration. It's got combat, platforming. Some puzzle work. A bit of everything. I dig it. You might too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998281238', 'num_games_owned': 4729, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1421789216}
review:
I loved this game, as it falls into my favorite genre of games: beat 'em ups.  It's just like Guacamelee Gold Edition except a few new areas, enemies, and one new boss.   However, since it is so much like its predecessor, I found the game to be very easy.  A few arenas here and there gave me a few problems, but overall it was a cakewalk.  The bosses are a joke and offer little to no challenge (except for the Jaguar boss, though I still think he was tougher in Gold Edition.)  Overall, I liked playing the game again; I just wish it offered more difficulty.

8/10

Weird that it's an entirely new game when it's practically just an update to Gold Edition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066339830', 'num_games_owned': 4107, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 1855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1415, 'last_played': 1421687635}
review:
A polished action 2d platformer.

This game is an 'upgrade' of previously released Guacamelee Gold Edition.

Looks simple, but when you play it - it's a bit complicated since it requires a bit of learning mostly for combos and memorizing the pattern of enemies' shields in order to break it. Chaining combos also feels smooth in battle, if you master it literally you'll stomp on enemies. 

There's a regular platformer features like Double Jump, Air Combo, but what's best from this game is that the game cleverly incorporates it but sometimes it's irritating and requiring you to replay a part of the level again and again because it requires precise movement and fast fingers. I also like the swapping dimension between living and the dead, required when you progress through the game - quickly reminds me to Giana Sisters Twisted Dream and to some extent, Soul Reaver. 

Game graphic overall I'm satisfied, it has unique feel for me. Certainly not pixel level. Performance wise, I play no problem on my mediocre 635m with highest quality settings available for me, no screen tearing, no sudden FPS drops.

Game's a platformer, and so as it stands it's best played with controller. While combos are easy to perform (only directional button + action button each), I'm not sure how fast my fingers would be had I played this with KB/M especially when you're required to be fast finger during a fight or moving thru a tricky level.

As for replayability, when you finish the game you're given hard level to beat. And achievements adding more appeal to come back and obtain. But for one simple playthrough, game's a bit short - I'm clocking at 6.5 hours or so for my first.

There's a leaderboard supposedly for bragging, but how someone beats the game less than 30 minutes baffles me to no end. I checked around and found it requires tricks, well.... not so good in my opinion.

Verdict, good game, but if you own previous title you'll be sorely disappointed that there's no loyalty discount anymore. I'd wait for a sale or bundle since the improvements are not worth 15 extra USDs alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058195030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1435440037}
review:
Easily one of the best side-scrolling brawlers of the last 15 years. Crisp controls, flawless level design, dedicated art style, various enemies, tons of hidden secrets and difficult challenges. Most important of all, the combat is superb. Every move is a staple in both fighting and platforming - nothing is wasted.

Amusing, frustrating at times, and good all around.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039319515', 'num_games_owned': 5530, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 2446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1315, 'last_played': 1654355393}
review: Epic game!! Por lejos el mejor platform que he jugado. Crear una sensaciÃ³n de mundo 3D en un 2D es un gran mÃ©rito. GrÃ¡ficamente sencillo, pero hermoso, buena mÃºsica, entretenida historia, hilarantes easter-eggs y referencias a otros juegos y un gameplay muy variado. Puedes volver a los lugares que ya recorriste y encontrar muchas cosas nuevas con las habilidades adquiridas. El sistema de batalla es simple, fluido y variado, todo es upgradeable, co-op, workshop, y un largo etcÃ©tera. Un MUST HAVE!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039363696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1421774576}
review:
I'm amazed at the prices this game has gone on sale for. I paid full price and feel I got a great deal.

This developer's love for video games shines in every facet of Guacamelee; the combat, platforming, the gameplay and control in general, the music, visual style, the presentation overall, are all stellar.

In addition to new areas and a boss, there are other changes in Super-Turbo-whatever including: a berserk mechanic, all specialty throws available by default, a new currency system for unlocking costumes, and probably more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996000877', 'num_games_owned': 636, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1409325319}
review:
This is basically the same game as Guacamelee Gold, except with a bit of added fluff. Please do not support dishonest business practices and just skip this game altogether. Having to rebuy the game again without even the slightest discount is in no way justifiable.

The technical aspects aren't much to look at either, the game either has huge input lag or A LOT of screen tearing, depending on your VSync settings. Pick your poison.

This game also still does not support online coop, despite the developer saying in the original game that he wanted to implement it, but did not have the time. Yet they apparently had enough time to re-release the same game with a few added skins and a few more enemies? Right...

I'd say vote with your wallet. The developers do not deserve your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119944574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1436482994}
review:
Within a few days, Guacamelee went from a cool demo I played for a few minutes to one of my favorite games of all time that I was putting hours into every night.

How I got to that point is simple: its FANTASTIC. A beat-em-up/platformer/metroidvania/whatever sounds like a lot but it doesnt feel like much in-game, where you can do pretty much whatever you want most of the time. You can explore, you can beat things into a pulp, you can throw a bunch of chickens into a wall--you can even BE a chicken! The learning curve builds up perfectly from familiar platforming and simple combos to nearly DMC-level battles and quite literally the single-hardest platforming section I have ever seen (and beaten). And do I even need to mention how beautiful the backgrounds and level design is?? It forced me to stop playing and just stare on some occasions. My screencap folder for this game is INSANE.

I have not played the Gold edition at all but if you're new to Guac like I was, this is the version I would recommend, hands down. If you're looking to upgrade from Gold, I'd still say go for it because I love it that much. I do know one of the new areas in this version is one of the largest in the game and gives a nice twist to the plot that I enjoyed, but that's something that either matters to you or not. I would especially sugest getting the soundtrack bundle of either version (I regret not getting it myself) simply because its amazing in the way it conbines the sounds of a retro sidescroller with traditional Mexican music.

The co-op is another thing I've yet to try, especially since 4-player is exclusive to this version, but everything I've seen of 2-player looked good. It definitely makes arenas easier, but I wouldn't do any especially challenging platforming on anything but single player. That stuff is hard enough to do alone sometimes, let alone trying to catch up when your partner is ahead. But if you just wanna screw with your friends, then go right ahead.

Some rumblings I've heard involve people saying the use of Mexican folklore here is racist, and as a Mexican with personal ties to that folklore, I heartily disagree. Yeah, its weird that a Canadian studio made an essentially Mexican game. But personally? It's not near the worst I've seen in terms of using sterotypes. And the accuracy and respect present in the style and lore of this game more than make up for that kind of stuff. It seriously feels like a love letter to a part of my culture that I hardly ever get to see in ANY media, let alone games, and we need more of it. I need to be able to walk up to another NPC singing "Cielito Lindo" at the top of their lungs for no reason. 

I'm THISCLOSE to fully completing the game (damn El Infierno challenges) but I'd definitely say I've gotten my money's worth out of it and more. My first playthrough went a bit longer than the average because I wanted the happy ending and that involves basically another playthrough worth of work. If 14.99 isn't that cool to you, its been on sale a lot in the short time I've had it so just stick it on the wishlist and be a little patient. It'll be worth it :)

11/10 would buy a sequel immediately

author: {'steamid': '76561197974211317', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1417925174}
review:
This game answers the question "What would Metroid be like if Samus was an undead luchador who could transform into a chicken?"

The platforming/exploring is solid and rewarding. The combat is fluid and fun. The art style is gloriously bright and colourful. The characters are suitably ridiculous. All-in-all, the game is a joyous experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980315480', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1419128603}
review: If you love metroidvania style games you'll adore this game. It's a great homage to the genre, and it brings its own flair and charm to the table. It's not too long to beat, I got 100% in most of the zones in 10ish hours. Combat is very fun too, with a good variety of enemies to test your skills against. There's tons of references to other retro and contemporary games as well which are fun to pick out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985770155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1288, 'last_played': 1535561932}
review:
Amazing game! Definetly the best Metroidvania I've played in years. Couldn't let my controller down. The gameplay is addictive, the pacing is wonderful, alot of old school game references and a good touch of humor.

Level design : 9.5/10 (Just cause perfection doesn't exist)
Combat design : 9.5/10 (Just cause perfection doesn't exist)
Sound design : 8/10
Graphics : 9/10

Overall, this game deserves a solid 9/10, it's absolutely amazing, you MUST try it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132578902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1418408904}
review: Don't get me wrong, Guacamelee is a pretty looking platformer with great fighting. There is just one major flaw in it that almost kill the experience for me. The developers substitute actual difficulty with piling so many enemies in a tiny room to where you can't tell what's going on and you can't see your character. There is so much shit going on in this tiny room that you can't hit anyone. The reason for that is when an enemy hits you, you get stunned for a split second. That isn't a problem with reasonable, spaced out enemies, but since there are so many enemies another one hits in your stunned faze. Then another. Then another. Then another. The only way to finish these kinds of room is to get lucky and hope you can keep from getting hit even once. If it weren't for this shitty "Small room, 500 enemies" thing, I would have a lot more fun with this game. I'm still going to finish it. Reluctantly. I recommend it if it's on sale. There are a lot of other amazing games that don't make you want to break your controller in half for $15.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011949271', 'num_games_owned': 983, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1417585525}
review:
Guacamelee is brilliant; tremendous; fan-fucking-tastic. If you're any sort of a fan of 2D platformers, buy it. The game is a triumph and I will recommend it to anybody. But that's not what this review is about. This review is about which version to buy.

There is much hoo-hah in the reviews here pertaining to the inclusion of Intenso mode, and the concurrent rebalancing of difficulty. I've beaten the original game twice - once on normal, and another time on hard - and I honestly didn't notice much of a difference. There are a few more enemies in some sections, but nothing that gave me any serious grief. If you're skilled you won't even need to use Intenso mode, but some people struggled with the difficulty of the original game, so I don't begrudge its inclusion. Think of it as an alterable in-game difficulty setting and if you don't like using easy mode, well then you won't need to use Intenso.

The purported remixing of existing levels is also very slight - basically a few new chests have been added and some old ones relocated. It's a non-event.

Perhaps most worthless is the new power-up, the Pollo Bomb. Once you've obtained it, pressing B while in the form of a chicken will make you lay an egg that explodes after a second or so, delivering a ridiculously small amount of damage to nearby enemies. There is literally no situation in which a pollo bomb would be preferable to straight-up melee. It only really serves to break a few new types of barrier rocks, which typically lead to some of the 'remixed' sections.

If you're not going to be using the 4-player co-op, which I haven't tested, this really only leaves the two new areas as an incentive to buy the game. And they're good - nothing has been half-assed, and they don't feel like they've been shoe-horned in. They fit in seamlessly on narrative, geographic and aesthetic levels. They offer an extra hour or two of fun gameplay. But that's all they offer.

So ultimately, if you don't own any version of Guacamelee at all, buying this one is a no-brainer - it has the most content, and is the must customisable to your ability as a gamer. However, if you already own Gold, you need to ask yourself how much 2 hours of gameplay is worth to you, because that's the only thing of substance STCE offers over Gold. To market it as a completely separate game really does seem like a cash-grab, as I see no reason this couldn't have been sold as relatively inexpensive DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024423322', 'num_games_owned': 1307, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1417116364}
review:
Also allein vom Titel kann Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition mit den Naruto-Titeln mithalten.
Aber das ist natÃ¼rlich nicht das Einzige, womit dieses Spiel punkten kann.
Die Geschichte mag jetzt erstmal simpel und nicht herausragend klingen:
Der Protagonist Juan Aguacate trÃ¤umte immer davon ein Luchador zu werden. Als wir eines Tages bei der Vorbereitung eines Festes helfen sollen, wird das Dorf von dem BÃ¶sewicht Calaca Ã¼berfallen, der die Welt der Lebenden und der Toten vereinen mÃ¶chte, und entfÃ¼hrt unsere â€Freundinâ€. NatÃ¼rlich liegt es an uns, seine Lakaien zu besiegen und die Tochter des PrÃ¤sidenten zurÃ¼ckzuholen.
Die Grafik ist super charmant, mir sind keinerlei MÃ¤ngel oder Bugs aufgefallen. Die Performance ist einwandfrei und mit dem Controller lÃ¤sst es sich extrem lÃ¤ssig, flott und simpel spielen. Womit Guacamelee! besonders hervorsticht, ist zum Einen der Humor und die Charaktere, sowohl die NPCs als auch der Protagonist und die ganzen Antagonisten.
Dazu die KostÃ¼me, die Steam-Workshop-Integration, inzwischen 4-Spieler-Coop! und weiteren Updates.
Zum Kampfsystem: Wie gesagt, erstmal ist es recht simpel, es gibt dennoch eine groÃŸe Vielfalt an Moves und man braucht fÃ¼r jeden Gegner eine andere Taktik. Es wird nie zu hektisch, man kann gut den Ãœberblick behalten und kommt auch schnell rein. 
Es gibt viele verschiedene Gegner, coole Bossfights und eine recht groÃŸe, offene Welt. Es gibt viele Upgrades zu entdecken und aus dem Grund, dass man nicht an alle Geheimnisse sofort kommt, kann man alle Gebiete spÃ¤ter nochmal besuchen.
Es gibt eine Schnellreisefunktion, womit man nicht soviel laufen muss, dann Challenges und eine 2. Schwierigkeitsstufe.
Normal war eine gute Mischung aus Einfach und etwas fummliger.
Bisschen mehr Tracks wÃ¤ren schÃ¶n gewesen, schlimm ist es aber auf keinen Fall, da die eingebauten in keiner Weise nerven oder an ihrer QualitÃ¤t verlieren.
Super Aktion auch, dass Besitzer der Gold Edition die neue Edition deutlich reduziert bekommen.
Absolute Empfehlung an alle Spieler! Sowohl Casual als auch Hardcore  - Coop oder Singleplayer - ich denke, dass mit Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition alle ihren SpaÃŸ dran haben werden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999110961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1417232903}
review:
Guacamelee is one of the best games I've ever played. I put it right next to Cave Story in my list of favorite indie games.

Guacamelee is a Metroidvania 2D-sidescrolling action game. Here are my personal highlights:

-Pacing and level design are both fantastic. The game introduces new powerups and abilities at a constant steady pace, which keeps the game feeling fresh the whole way through. Every powerup you unlock opens up new areas in past locations you've already visited, with new goodies to discover in each.
-Combat is fun and easy enough to understand. It's pure melee action and rewards you for chaining combos of different moves. It gives you full freedom to pull off different combos of all sorts.
-Art style is stylish, gorgeous, and makes good use of Mesoamerican cultural references/imagery in a respectful manner.
-The soundtrack fits all of the different (Mexican) environments perfectly. I don't think the developers (in Canada) had a single person of Mexican descent on their team when they made this game... but I can tell they did their homework on Mexican culture.
-Lots of clever easter eggs and references to other games like Metroid, Mario, Zelda, and other indie games. It was fun spotting them all.

I didn't really find anything to fault the game for, other than that it never recognized my USB gamepad, so I had to play it with my keyboard. It was still enjoyable despite that though. If you have a Xbox 360 controller (I don't, mine's a generic USB pad) you likely won't have this problem.

I definitely recommend this game! It deserves every bit of praise it gets. I sadly never got to try out the 2-4 player co-op multiplayer, but I imagine that would only have made it even more enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041354567', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1420012966}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197999339665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1416575896}
review:
Para cualquiera que no conozca el colorido mundo de Guacamelee! y se quiera adentrar en Ã©l, esta Super Turbo Championship Edition es claramente la ediciÃ³n definitiva por la que dar comienzo a una nueva vida llena de alegrÃ­as. En toda su [i]metroidvaniedad[/i], es mejor Metroid que Metroid, y mejor Castlevania que Castlevania. Puede sonar exagerado, pero no hay mÃ¡s que adentrarse en su vorÃ¡gine de combos, movimientos especiales, humor descarriado, mecÃ¡nicas pulidÃ­simas y decenas de secretos escondidos, para ver que se trata de uno de los mejores juegos de la Ãºltima dÃ©cada.

Si por el contrario ya se ha jugado y/o terminado cualquiera de las ediciones anteriores, comprar esta entrega sin un descuento importante puede resultar absurdo. No por las novedades, que son pocas pero interesantes, sino por el hecho de que, en el fondo, sigue siendo el mismo juego capaz de enamorar a cualquiera.

A mÃ­ ese amor me ha llevado a terminarlo de nuevo al 100%, pero dependerÃ¡ de cada uno valorar si lo suyo con Guacamelee! es un muy intenso rollo de verano, o un amor para toda la vida.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079169593', 'num_games_owned': 4638, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1582749313}
review:
IMHO only. Remember, I didn't like the original edition at all and I tried to give this version a try.

This "Super Turbo Championship Edition" changed a "meh" game to a "super-ultra-mega-shocking-wow" game. The first time I played the original" version, I didn't like it (idk exactly why, maybe the controls, the colors or simply I found it a boring game). As I started playing the Super Turbo Championship Edition, man, taht's great, all fluid and you feel like you're inside the game. This version caught me and I strongly recommend it! 

If you liked the original edition or you were kinda disappointed, give this a try. It is worth!

[b]Devs[/b], congratulations for all hard work! It is an awesome game now! It is really FUN (nice to be played, smooth), as all games should be. Thank you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021012355', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1415761458}
review:
10/10

Imagine you took Metroid, Final Fight and Lucha Libre and put it in a blender, then you poured that all over the sexiest person you can think of and made love to him/her for 24 hours straight. Then after you are done, you are given a billion dollars, the title of King of the World, and a back rub. That's Guacamelee in a hyperbole enfused nutshell.

In all seriousness, Guacamelee has precision platforming; challenging, old school, pattern based combat; addictive music; actual funny humor; and its a friggin Metroidvania. Plus its gorgeous... It is quite possibly the best game (of the retro-esque platform/combat style) that I've played in years. Definately the best Metroidvania since Monster Tale on the DS, its secrets are not super hard to find, but the skill required to get 100% more than makes up for the slightly easy to find items, and many of the abilities make the back and forth nature of this type of game much less tedious, as almost all of them are movement based in one way or another. There is nothing that I can complain about this game, except maybe that there are no sequels yet, or maybe that its only about 12 hours long for a 100% play through.

review:
I can barely think of anything I DON'T like about this game.  How could I possibly find fault with a Mexican-flavored side-scrolling dimension-swapping metroidvania comedy beat-em-up set on DÃ­a de los Muertos?

The combat is exciting, the controls are tight, you will NEVER run out of different ways to beat people up, platforming is immensely satisfying and makes good use of the special moves, it's chock full of those little moments that make you go "woah!", consequenses for failure are low and put you back in the action right away, you spend a significant portion of the game as a chicken...

Just fuggin' buy it already, it's awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015327809', 'num_games_owned': 1111, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1415505798}
review: Vanilla Guacamelee really burned me hard because for the majority of the game I really was enjoying it due to the gameplay and atmosphere up until the difficulty scaling went out right the window with Jaguar Javier and I just gave up there. Thankfully Super Turbo has fixed most of these problems and the ball-busting stuff is relegated to 100% completion as it should be. Intenso is also a solid enough way to make things somewhat easier while leaving it optional. The levels and boss that they added in Super Turbo are nice additions that are worth 5 bucks if you already own Vanilla. Overall if you haven't bought Guacamelee yet just buy this, its standalone and an improvement over Vanilla. If you want more Guacamelee or felt really burned by Vanilla give Super Turbo a spin, its what I wanted the game to be from the beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984290474', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1414725073}
review:
If someone told you about a game that was a cross between Metroidvania and Double Dragon where you play as a Luchador wrestler that can transform into a chicken and who learns his special moves from a half-goat-half-man during the Dia De Los Muertos Festival, you'd be perfectly within your rights to assume that the individual in question was insane.

Thankfully for the world, the game actually does exist, and it's brilliant.

It's kinda nice to have a game with themes that come from somewhere other than Japan or the United States, even if nothing in Guacamelee should be taken seriously, vis-a-vis the reality of life in Central America. All of the stages and characters are beautifully crafted in a slightly demented sort of way, the fighting flows wonderfully, and the upgrade system is easy to use.

As for differences between Super Turbo Championship Edition and Gold Edition, there is a new boss, a few new regular enemies, two new stages, a few new music tracks, a new special power, and a heavily revised "Hard Mode" - which is many orders of magnitude more diffcult in STCE than it was in the Gold Edition.

In all, I honestly can't think of anything bad to say about the game... Like... At all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978705200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1415036425}
review:
Hmm..
Naturally when you're looking to buy a game, you want to get the latest and greatest version. It should have all the extra content, bug-fixes, and so on. However, the possibility exists that the newest verson could be inferior in some ways. Game-design is a constant and always finicky, and nobody ever seems to be satisfied with its results. So things get changed, and changed again, sometimes they're even changed back to their original state. It's a constantly confusing nightmare, and for what? In the end it all comes down to preference.

Forgive me, I love to ramble.

STCE is on paper*, the superior version of Guacamelee! Let's look at some of the facts:

Two brand-new areas to explore!
A new boss-fight!
Intenso!
Multiple save-slots!
New enemies!
Every foe has a visible health-meter!
etc!

If you're hankering for more Guacamelee, then definitely grab this! The new areas are great. They make the world a bit richer, and are fleshed out with plenty of secrets and fighting/platforming to be had. I also like the little changes such as costumes being unlocked via silver coins. The biggest deal is that the controller-issue I had with Guaca-Gold is fixed, making this by default the superior version for me.

BUT!
STCE is a different game, and it can be considered inferior in a way. The controversial addition is Intenso! It's the "shock gloves"** of Guacamelee. Once you fill a meter you can become a superpowered luchadore by pressing L3+R3. Once you purchase all of the upgrades you're practically invincible. Guaca-Gold wasn't a difficult game, so having the ability to cheese the rare moments of challenge makes things a bit too easy. Keep in mind that this ability is optional. Most of the time I forgot I even had it. 

The new enemies are quaint. For the most part they're reskins that can move faster, hit (much) harder, and will sometimes teleport to get out of danger. Aside from nega-chupacabras doing tons of damage with their sword-stab, they're not a threat. There are also some flying fish in one of the new areas. They remind me of enemies from the Saturn version of Symphony of the Night. They only showed up in one area, and behaved in a similar manner. If it's a reference, then I applaud drinkbox for their attention to obscurity.

If you haven't played Guacamelee before, IMO it's best to go straight to this version. It's more convenient, since the original version doesn't have multiple save-slots. Having the most content is a definite plus as well. You might feel the urge to go back to Guaca-Gold for its original "true" level of difficulty but eh...I wouldn't recommend it. Most of Guacamelee's challenge is in a couple of boss-fights, and the optional areas like El Infierno. For the most part you're the awesome skull-cracking luchadore on a fun adventure. If you want a difficult Metroidvania, consider Valdis Story: Abyssal City (also on Steam).

Mostly though I'm just really happy and relieved that the controller issue I had with Guaca-Gold is fixed in this game. It's the main reason I'll probably never go back to the earlier version (though I have a fair number of achievements I should get).




*What is it with "on paper"? I use that phrase way too often.

**The gloves from Batman: Arkham Origins. Punch through any defense, combo count boost, makes things so easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 1247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1448399662}
review:
It's Guacamelee, except with more stuff. And the new stuff is pretty good, though maybe a bit misplaced in the game's timeline; the second new area especially has several things harder than anything else in the game, /including/ the secret areas :B
Hard mode also has platforming challenges changed a little, which actually feels unnecessary but it's not a huge change. It's still the same luchadorvania that I enjoyed the first time through. Still not perfect but plenty fun. Worth picking up if you never played the original Gold edition, probably worth it on sale if you have.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4499, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1413630926}
review:
Edit: my review of the old Guacamelee version still applies, but also could in mind that I felt this version felt like a whole new game. Make of that what you will.

Guacamelee is one of the best Metroidvania games in years. I immensely enjoyed it. The game's graphics are just perfect with tons of detail and color. The gameplay is great, too.You'll unlock moves by buying them or by completing parts of the story. These new powers will help you find secrets in previously played parts and open up new parts of the story. 

There are a couple of sidequests, but they can be finished rather quickly. One or two of them are fairly lengthy, however, all things considered. 

Guacamelee is not a long game, I think I completed it in 8 hours or so, so I hope that a possible sequel will be longer. It's just so much fun.  Drinkbox's previous game was also kinda short. A real shame, because their games are great and feature the same kind of graphical styles.

But the game's not perfect. Battle arenas can become frustrating because they're limited in space and a few of them are timer dependent. The arenas do help you practice for bossfights though; those can get pretty hectic and intense.

This game was released on the same day as Papers Please and Spelunky and if I had to pick one of these games Guacamelee would be my first choice. Papers Please would definitely grab the second place.

For those guys that think: 'TL:DR'; let me say this with my best Star Wars voice: Guacamelee is the game you're looking for.

[quote]If you enjoyed this review please consider following me: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41144728-markdj/]curator page[/url] [/quote]

review: This game is surprising. I had seen some different things about it, but I didn't even know it was a sidescrolling platformer. Then I saw some gameplay. I immediately sunk 30 hours in one week, and now, another week later, a total of 40 hours. I have played through it on a normal 100% run, hard 100% run, normal speedrun, hard speedrun, then another 100% speedrun on normal. Insanely fun. 10/10 for me. Fun, visually pleasing, tight controls, and replayable beyond belief.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991054974', 'num_games_owned': 910, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 981, 'last_played': 1412481111}
review:
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition is the remake of Guacamelee! Gold Edition.  On it's own it is a fantastic throw-back to Metroid-style platforming, exploration, and "weapon" upgrades that aid combat, mobility, and access to new areas (the weapons being your fists, btw).  It is a remarkable well put together game of roughly the same length as Super Metroid, perhaps a tad shorter.  
A solid 10/10 if you're into number rankings. Definitely worth the money, and the time and effort you'll put into getting 100% and playing hardcore mode.

The caveat:
If you already own Gold Edition, I'm not sure this is worth the entry price.  I had and completed Gold Edition shortly after it came out last year.  Not wanting to spend money on this remake without knowing what made it different I finagled myself a copy through trading.  For those who have Gold Edition and are curious, the biggest CHANGE is enemy behavior.  It is slightly more difficult to scum your special attacks ad nauseum.  Another change is that costumes cost a second "silver" currency which is much more rare than the gold.  And the additions amount to 3 new areas with a total extra ~2 hours of gameplay (depending on your play style).  The other addition, which I never found necessary to use is a Turbo mode which makes Juan faster and more powerful for a limited amount of time. And finally you can drop an egg bomb as a chicken.

Are these changes and additions worth $5 to someone who already owns and has played Gold Edition?  Well, that's entirely subjective.  In retrospect I'm glad I didn't spend the money for the remake, but I am glad I got to play it.  I truly love this game, and if it was made 20 years ago I think people would still be hype about it today.

tl;dr
Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition is worth every penny to a Guacamelee noobie, and is a crapshoot if you've got Gold Edition.
Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992229015', 'num_games_owned': 1184, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 853, 'last_played': 1411612859}
review: Great game just in general. A really nice platformer/brawler with interesting mechanics, such as turning into a chicken, switching between the dead and living world and combining different moves to get from a to b or to defeat certain enemies. Certainly nothing revolutionary and the story is ... well ...sometimes it has its funny moments. The luchador and "day of the dead" theme in general is pretty cool though. Would pick it up for about 10 bucks. Should keep you occupied for about 8 hours I guess. The amount of backtracking is definitely ok, since you will be revisiting many areas as the story progresses so I never had to "go out of my way" to get to new areas. You can also view all maps on the map screen and blocked areas are easy to spot as well as to how to get past them (dimension shift, pollo power or red, blue, green, yellow blocks). Combat is extremely responsive. All in all a solid 8/10 if you need a scale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085982257', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1418660068}
review: Dopo aver finito Guacamelee! Gold Edition al 100% non potevo non acquistare la versione definitiva, la Super TurboMegaOverMotherFuckingEpicPower Championship Edition. Ma la vera domanda Ã¨: vale la pena acquistare un gioco quando lo si possiede giÃ ? In sostanza Ã¨ pur sempre Guacamelee, stesso stile grafico, stesso sistema di combattimento e stessa trama, anche se con qualche ritocco qua e lÃ . Quindi, in definitiva, il gioco vale la candela? Assolutamente sÃ¬. Ho completato volentieri per ben due volte questa espansione (anche se non si tratta di un vero e proprio DLC) e nonostante tutto mi sono divertito come se lo giocassi per la prima volta. Il sistema di combattimento ha qualche chicca in piÃ¹, come l'abilitÃ  INTENSO grazie alla quale la nostra forza verrÃ  aumentata notevolmente, ci sono nuovi tipi di nemici, tra cui quelli Elite, molto piÃ¹ forti del normale e, probabilmente l'aggiunta piÃ¹ importante, la presenza di una nuova area con tanto di boss aggiuntivo. In conclusione, se possedete giÃ  la Gold Edition, consiglio l'acquisto solo se avete veramente amato questo titolo, se invece ne siete sprovvisti... Bhe, rimediate subito con la Super Turbo Championship Edition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108223735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1410329638}
review:
Since I hv played the Gold Edition, perfected it and also wrote a review about it, Im gonna focus on whats new and different about the two games.

+ Multiple save slots. I dun really get why they need to put this feature, possibly for players that wants to share the game with friends and family or something.
+ New areas to explore (also comes with new music) and also a new boss(not gonna spoil too much on that)
+ New Moves and the addition of the Intenso mode which is like the powerup mode to bash through enemies easier.
+ New enemies that are a bit harder to kill, which requires the use of Intenso mode

The game feels like a dlc to Gold Edition but as an individual game, is as good as Gold Edition! Plus if u bought the gold edition u can get a discount for it!

The new areas and secrets are great addition to the game, the music is wonderful, the enemies are still enjoyable to fight and overall, STILL a very good, well done game.

Sometimes the Intenso mode can be a little bit overpowerful, making the hard mode for STCE in my opinion not as hard as Gold edition but then again maybe its just because I played this game 3 times already and kinda got a feel to it, haha.

10/10, would still play again. XD

author: {'steamid': '76561197966865999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1629074497}
review:
I wrote a review for Guacamelee! Gold Edition a little less than a year ago, and it still hold true to this version of the game.  

I do like the additions that they added (a couple of moves for your chicken form, two extra zones and an extra boss and the El Intenso ability).  Even though they feel a little where they just threw them in, it is probably because since I played the Gold Edition, that is probably why.  I feel that if someone were to only play this version of Guacamelee! for the first time, it would feel natual.  I feel that we could of done without the El Intenso ability.  It felt like a ability that gave me a free pass through areas I just didn't want to deal with.

The change they did to make it easier to get the other outfits was very welcome.  With the Gold Edition, I didn't get any of them because you had to get them late game and by that time, you had pretty much beaten the game, so you didn't really have to use them.  This way, you can not get them earlier in the game and they help with your play style.  I found myself using them more due to it and I really liked that.

As I said in my Gold Edition review of Guacamelee!, if you are a fan of Metroidvania style games, this one doesn't disappoint, one of the few games that I beat and want to go back to try and get all the items/achievements even though it can be tough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016003941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1595593251}
review:
it's a weird one...the game starts off with a lot of charm and character. the presentation is strong and the soundtrack is great. The first few hours are fun but then you realise you are just sprinting through a kind of meaningless world fluffed up with pointless, heard it before dialogue that is really cliche!! And enemies that prove no challenge whatsoever...

It starts to feel more and more like a game for kids...and the gameplay becomes really repetitive. You find a village with pointless people saying pointless things. You progress towards a temple of sorts through an easy landscape utilising the predictable power ups that every other game under the sun has offered you in the past. Then it hits you...there is no game nor game world...just a tonne of square blocks making rooms that close and expect you to fight pointless enemies again and again.

The added complexity of shields on enemies does not make it any more enjoyable...just a lot more annoying. You spend hours, finger fuck!ing your controller, doing double jumps followed by uppercuts followed by this and that to just navigate and it becomes a chore. Nothing...nothing like Hollow Knight or even Ori. Movement was enjoyable in those games...this game is a fuck!ng chore!!

I got up to the last section and gave up...it's just so fuck!ng boring and repetitive...no doubt fun for kids with little experience but do avoid if you've seen your fair share of games. There is nothing new here to see and only more of the same ol' sh!t that you've probably played before in other great games...shame...i tried to like it...

author: {'steamid': '76561198044746170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1408741580}
review:
Just a heads up tp those who own the Gold Edition. This is NOT a cash grab with a couple of levels tacked on, it's a complete overhaul. The new levels are fully integrated into the base game. Certain pathways that were accessible in the original are blocked off in this game, and require the use of new abilities needed to traverse parts of the new levels.

  The new abilities are available early on, and required a complete rebalancing  of all prior enemies. The new enemies, traps, and levels, are much more challenging. The difficulty ramps up steadily to the point of frustration, but that makes it all the sweeter when you finally manage to get past a difficult section.

  If you enjoyed the Gold Edition, you'll enjoy this one even more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004291532', 'num_games_owned': 2601, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1544, 'last_played': 1409134775}
review:
The original Guacamelee! is one of my favorite "Indie" games that I own, and I was extremely excited when I heard that the Super Tubo Championship Edition came to PC. I purchased it immediately and just finished my Normal playthrough.

Guacamelee!: Super Turbo Championship Edition adds a good amount of extra content, in the form of new levels, new enemies scattered throughout the game, a new boss, and new abilities. It's a "Metroidvania" style 2D action game, but instead of a bounty hunter or vampire hunter, you play as Guacamelee!, a luchador fighting his way through both the land of the living and the dead to rescue his love.

The Good:

*Unique art style drawing from Mexican folklore, specifically the "Day of the Dead"
*Great music and environments
*Tight controls
*Clever, rarely frustrating platforming sections
*Fun combat, with a mix of combo-based striking and grappling
*Simple story with humor and references to classic games all over every stage of the game

The Bad:
*Can't remap controls on a controller. This is a minor gripe, because the controls make sense, except for the new "Intenso" mode, which requires pressing LS and RS simultaneously on a gamepad. This is annoying, especially considering that RB and RT are both mapped to the same function, and either could have been switched to Intenso mode.
*Game is short. I wanted it to last longer. There is replayability in a Hard mode unlock and a challenge guantlet of sorts, with lots of hidden items to go back and find for 100% completion. But even with the added content, I beat the game in 9 hours (not 100%), with a considerable amount of backtracking and exploration.
*The new Intenso mode makes combat far too easy on Normal playthrough. Entering Intenso mode lets you just wail on anything until it runs out, forgoing combos and dodging entirely.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game. As an owner of the original Guacamelee!, I received the upgrade at a discount (67% off, or $5). I had no issues replaying the game from scratch, because it's fun. I'd be less likely to recommend the upgrade to existing Guacamelee! owners at $15, because there's not THAT much new content. For new owners, however, $15 is absolutely worth it, even with the short length of the game. You'll want to get 100% completion, and then tackle Hard mode if you still haven't had enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050022561', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1410190953}
review:
Guacamelee is awesome. It's got impressive art style, gameplay is tight and music is great. 

The best part of it is combat system. It's fluid and fast. You combine regular kicks and special moves into spectacular combos, finishing of enemies with piledrivers, throws and slams. Dodging is easy, so combat in this game is more about fun then frustrating challenge(unless you'll go for OPTIONAL stuff to get achievments). 

Platforming gets gradualy more difficult and more creative as you learn new moves, but it won't be a problem(unless you'll go for OPTIONAL stuff to get achievments).

The world is huge and different, all areas are themed. Exploring it and finding hidden chests with upgrades is fun. Sometimes to get to the chest you'll have to beat platforming puzzles, sometimes combat challenges. There're also some side quest, which are mostly there for comedy reasons. Guys at Drinkbox generaly have a good sense of humor. You'll find a lot of references to your favourite indie and childhood games. 

The plot is simple, yet characters are different and weird(in a good way). Every big area ends with a boss fight of sort. I don't know, the game is generaly crafted so well, I'd call it a masterpiece. Go get it!

PS. I've beaten Gold Edition and now replaying this version on a Hard Mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972422416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1410011252}
review:
I am sorry Guacamelee - I really tried to give you another chance, I really did.  The look of your world is so great, and your humor and music just wonderful.

The first few hours of the game is also pretty fun. But then somewhere along the way it seems the developers got too full of themselves, and resorted to cheap and frustrating gameplay mechanics. Spikes, time pressure, crazy difficuly jumps you have to make it through, fights made more difficult by just increasing the amount of enemies, insanely frustrating and unskippable boss battles. There is so much bad game design here, and whoever designed some of these jumping puzzles should never be allowed to design games again.

After giving up the first time I knew it was naive of me to hope for anything better in this version, but I got the impression it was made more balanced and forgiving. It appears that very little has changed at all. Even the addition of the "Intenso" mode does little to improve the gameplay. What they *should* have done was make an Easy mode for those of us who want to enjoy the story and platforming without obsessing over stupid combos and trick jumps for hours on end, and give the option to skip the bloody boss fights. 

SO, got that out of my system.
